EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moved from the Central Plains into the Great Lakes region.  Snow developed out of this system late in the day on November 30th, and continued through a good part of December 1st.  Snowfall totals of around a foot were common in a band arcing from just west of Traverse City, northeastward into Eastern Upper Michigan.  Trout Lake picked up 17 inches of snow, East Jordan had around 15 inches, and Interlochen right around a foot.

Westerly winds behind a departing low pressure system kicked up locally heavy lake effect snow.  In Eastern Upper Michigan, the Paradise and Tahquamenon Falls area picked up around 10 inches of snow during the afternoon and night of the 4th.  Very heavy snow impacted parts of Northern Lower Michigan, with isolated snowfall rates of 4 to 5 inches per hour at times on the evening of the 4th, just west of Gaylord.  Places from Gaylord to Alba had between 10 and 15 inches of new snow my morning on the 5th.  A bit to the north, places just south of Indian River also picked up just over a foot of snow.

A low pressure system moved from central Illinois to central Ohio, with heavy snow falling north of the track of the low.  Northern Michigan was grazed by the north end of the swath of heavy snow.  Six to nine inch accumulations were common, southeast of a line from Lake City to Harrisville.  McBain picked up around 9 inches of snow, while Gladwin and Sterling had around 8 inches.

Two periods of snow affected Northern Michigan.  On the 23rd, a pair of upper level disturbances brought 1 to 4 inches of snow to the area.  After a break in the pre-dawn hours, low pressure brought locally heavier snow to the region on the 24th.  Atlanta picked up 9 inches of snow, McBain 8 inches, and Leland 6 inches.

Strong winds affected much of the area behind a strong cold front. Sustained winds of 25 to 35 mph were common with gusts in the 50 to 60 mph range. Some damage was reported in the White Pigeon area from the strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sturgis Michigan AWOS unit recorded a wind gust to 58 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The coldest air of the winter so far invaded Northern Michigan from the 18th to the 21st.  In most of the area, the air was too cold to support heavy lake effect snow.  But in Eastern Upper Michigan, the longer upstream fetch over Lake Superior allowed heavy snow to develop.  Paradise, Whitefish Point, and Tahquamenon Falls saw up to a foot of snow during the night of the 18th into the morning of the 19th.  And the snow kept on coming, with local six inch accumulations per twenty-four hours continuing through the night of the 20th.

A passing low pressure system brought a few inches of snow to parts of Northern Lower Michigan, mainly south of M-32, during the night of the 21st.  However, the snow was heavy in parts of Gladwin County, with six to eight inches of accumulation in and south of the city of Gladwin.

While a broad area of snow was passing just to the south, a narrow band of heavy lake effect snow impacted Emmet County.  Cross Village picked up just short of a foot of snow during the evening and early overnight hours of the 21st.

Cold and gusty west winds brought locally heavy lake effect snow off of Lake Michigan.  Boyne Falls picked up eight inches of snow during the day and night of the 22nd, while Petoskey received six inches.  Considerable blowing and drifting snow also occurred.

Cold and gusty west winds brought locally heavy lake effect snow off of Lake Michigan.  Boyne Falls picked up eight inches of snow during the day and night of the 22nd, while Petoskey received six inches.  Considerable blowing and drifting snow also occurred.

Light north winds produced a single band of heavy lake effect in coastal Manistee County.  Accumulations of six to seven inches occurred in and north of the city of Manistee, during the evening and early overnight hours of the 23rd into the 24th.

Unseasonably warm, moist air was drawn north into the area ahead of a strong cold front that moved from Illinois into southwestern lower Michigan during the evening hours of January 7. Surface temperatures in the 60s and dewpoints in the 50s, as well as strong winds aloft, allowed for the development of a line of strong to severe thunderstorms along the cold front in Illinois. This line progressed east into far southwestern lower Michigan with reports of wind damage being received. The line quickly weakened as it moved east and transitioned into a heavy rain event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were blown down in Dowagiac.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably warm, moist air was drawn north into the area ahead of a strong cold front that moved from Illinois into southwestern lower Michigan during the evening hours of January 7. Surface temperatures in the 60s and dewpoints in the 50s, as well as strong winds aloft, allowed for the development of a line of strong to severe thunderstorms along the cold front in Illinois. This line progressed east into far southwestern lower Michigan with reports of wind damage being received. The line quickly weakened as it moved east and transitioned into a heavy rain event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was blown down two miles west of Sherwood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably warm, moist air was drawn north into the area ahead of a strong cold front that moved from Illinois into southwestern lower Michigan during the evening hours of January 7. Surface temperatures in the 60s and dewpoints in the 50s, as well as strong winds aloft, allowed for the development of a line of strong to severe thunderstorms along the cold front in Illinois. This line progressed east into far southwestern lower Michigan with reports of wind damage being received. The line quickly weakened as it moved east and transitioned into a heavy rain event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter recorded a wind gust of 65 mph five miles north of Coldwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a brief thaw, a strong cold front blasted Arctic air back into Northern Michigan.  Wind gusts behind the front reached 65 mph in Ossineke, and 63 mph in Charlevoix.  The cold air rushing in over the Great Lakes resulted in 1 to 3 inches of snow in much of Eastern Upper and Northwest Lower Michigan.  The snow and wind resulted in near-blizzard conditions for a few hours on the morning of the 28th.  Visibilities of a half-mile or less were common.

Another strong cold front, accompanied by developing low pressure, resulted in snow across much of far southern Lower Michigan. While the highest amounts were only around 4 inches, strong winds caused widespread blowing and drifting with white-out conditions at times. In addition, wind chills dropped into the 15 to 25 below zero range.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported just over 4 inches of snow in Berrien Springs, along with whiteout conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A blast of arctic air flowed over the relatively warm waters of Lake Michigan to allow for the development of lake effect snow showers. One band in particular dropped heavy snow across portions of Berrien county. Brisk winds also caused area of blowing and drifting as well as wind chills around 20 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters in the Stevensville area reported a storm total accumulation of 8.6 inches, with nearly 6 inches of this falling within a 6 hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds affected much of the area behind a strong cold front. Sustained winds of 25 to 35 mph were common with gusts in the 50 to 60 mph range. Some damage was reported in the White Pigeon area from the strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported an antenna blown over and snapped in half during the overnight hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved from the Central Plains to Southern Lower Michigan, producing heavy snow north of the track of the low.  In Northern Michigan, the heavier snow fell near and southeast of a line from Manistee to Alpena.  Total accumulations of 10 to 14 inches were common near Gladwin, West Branch, Hale, and Black River.

A slow-moving low pressure system crossed the Great Lakes region on the 21st.  Two areas of heavy snow occurred.  The first occurred in parts of Northeast Lower Michigan, as east winds off of Lake Huron enhanced snowfall at the start of the event.  Rogers City picked up 8 inches of snow by mid-morning on the 21st.  After that, very heavy snow developed in parts of Northwest Lower Michigan, on the northwest flank of the low pressure system.  Wellston ended up with 23 inches of snow in 23 hours, while Meauwataka picked up 16 inches.

Abundant low level moisture trapped under drier air aloft resulted in periods of widespread dense fog across portions of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 2nd through the morning of the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense fog reported throughout much of the period at the Sawyer International Airport AWOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant low level moisture trapped under drier air aloft resulted in periods of widespread dense fog across portions of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 2nd through the morning of the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense fog reported at the Menominee County Airport AWOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant low level moisture trapped under drier air aloft resulted in periods of widespread dense fog across portions of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 2nd through the morning of the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread dense fog reported throughout the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant low level moisture trapped under drier air aloft resulted in periods of widespread dense fog across portions of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 2nd through the morning of the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense fog reported throughout much of the period at the Manistique AWOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Locally moderate to heavy lake effect snow fell over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 8th through the morning of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers between McMillan and Newberry reported eight inches of heavy lake effect snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Locally moderate to heavy lake effect snow fell over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 8th through the morning of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Rockland reported 5.9 inches of snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northerly flow of colder air across Lake Superior in the wake of an Alberta clipper system brought heavy lake snow to portions of central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 19th through the evening of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer seven miles north of Soo Junction measured a two-day snowfall total of 25 inches. Tahquamenon Area schools were closed on the 21st due to the heavy lake effect snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system brought snow to the Northern Great Lakes region.  Locally heavy snow developed in parts of Northwest Lower Michigan on the evening of the 30th, with Lake Ann picking up 13 inches of snow by morning of the 1st.  However, for most of the region, the heaviest snow fell on the 1st.  Thus, a more complete disucssion of this event will be contained in Storm Data for December 2008.

Cold northwest winds moving across the relatively warm waters of Lake Michigan, produced locally heavy lake effect snow in parts of Northern Lower Michigan.  Six to eight inches of snow fell in Alba, Mancelona, and between Elmira and Boyne City, on the night of the 16th.

Cold northwest winds moving across the relatively warm waters of Lake Michigan, produced locally heavy lake effect snow in parts of Northern Lower Michigan.  Six to eight inches of snow fell in Alba, Mancelona, and between Elmira and Boyne City, on the night of the 16th.

An Alberta Clipper moved through the Northern Great Lakes on the 19th, producing mostly light snow.  However, southwest winds ahead of the clipper scooped up extra moisture from Lake Michigan, and then dumped locally heavy snow on parts of Eastern Upper Michigan.  Raber picked up 10 inches of snow, Tahquamenon Falls had just over 9 inches, while Engadine had 8 and Sault Ste Marie, 7 inches.

Colder air surged into the region behind a departing Alberta Clipper.  This kicked off locally heavy lake effect snow downwind of Lake Michigan.  Bellaire, Manton, Lake Ann, and Beulah were among the communties that picked up around 8 inches of snow.

A strong low pressure system produced very windy conditions across southwestern lower Michigan on December the 28th.  The highest wind gusts occurred mainly before sunrise, however very gusty conditions persisted well into the afternoon.  Hundreds of thousands of people across the state lost power at least temporarily due to high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated at 60 mph were recorded.  Central dispatch reported that numerous trees and power lines were blown down across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system produced very windy conditions across southwestern lower Michigan on December the 28th.  The highest wind gusts occurred mainly before sunrise, however very gusty conditions persisted well into the afternoon.  Hundreds of thousands of people across the state lost power at least temporarily due to high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts up to 60 mph brought down several trees and power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values hovered around 25 below zero on the morning of the 16th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values plunged into the 25 to 35 below zero range during the period.  Ewen-Trout Creek Schools closed on the 16th due to the bitter cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values dropped near 25 below zero on the morning of the 16th. Many Dickinson County schools were operating on a two-hour delay.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved into the western Great Lakes on the 14th, along an arctic cold front.  Most of the associated snow in Northern Michigan was light, but a narrow band of heavy snow impacted parts of Central Lower Michigan.  Manistee picked up a foot of snow, while Wellston received almost ten inches.
Lake effect snow developed in the wake of a cold front and became heavy at times for the northwest wind snowbelts from the 3rd into the 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Ironwood measured 12 inches of snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed in the wake of a cold front and became heavy at times for the northwest wind snowbelts from the 3rd into the 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Rockland measured eight inches of snow in 12 hours and a storm total snowfall of 19.1 inches ending on the evening of the 4th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values dropped between 25 and 30 below zero on the morning of the 16th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values plummeted to 25 to 30 below zero on the morning of the 16th as Marquette area schools closed due to the cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary low pressure trough over central Lake Superior focused heavy lake effect snow showers over Keweenaw County on the 17th into the morning of the 18th. As the trough sagged slowly south...heavy lake effect snow then became focused over north central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 18th into the morning of 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lake Linden observer measured 6 inches of snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary low pressure trough over central Lake Superior focused heavy lake effect snow showers over Keweenaw County on the 17th into the morning of the 18th. As the trough sagged slowly south...heavy lake effect snow then became focused over north central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 18th into the morning of 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of 12 inches of lake effect snow in Deerton. Most of the snow fell during the afternoon and evening of the 19th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front blasted portions of Upper Michigan with blizzard to near-blizzard conditions and occasional heavy snow on the 6th and 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters from Traunik to Trenary and east to Melstrand reported whiteout conditions in heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow along with frequent wind gusts to 35 mph or greater on the 6th.  At least a foot of snow was reported at Traunik and Melstrand during the blizzard event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front blasted portions of Upper Michigan with blizzard to near-blizzard conditions and occasional heavy snow on the 6th and 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were extrapolated over northern Schoolcraft County on the 6th due to the blizzard conditions reported near Shingleton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front blasted portions of Upper Michigan with blizzard to near-blizzard conditions and occasional heavy snow on the 6th and 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Occasional whiteout conditions were reported across the county as winds gusted over 30 mph at times. The spotter five miles west of Houghton reported 6 inches of snow in less than 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow bands dropped locally heavy snow from Rockland and Mass City to Twin Lakes on the 11th and 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters in Rockland and Mass City reported eight inches of snow in the 12-hour period ending at 9 pm on the 11th. The spotter in Rockland reported four inches of snow between 530 pm and 9 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow bands dropped locally heavy snow from Rockland and Mass City to Twin Lakes on the 11th and 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter at Twin Lakes measured 9.5 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mohawk observer reported whiteout conditions throughout the day.  Keweenaw County schools were closed on the 15th due to the blizzard conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southwestern lower Michigan experienced a mix of precipitation from the afternoon of December the 8th through the 9th. Due to warmer temperatures farther south near the I-94 corridor, precipitation was mainly rain with some freezing rain across that area. ||The first burst of precipitation spread northeast over southwest lower Michigan during the early evening hours of the 8th. Near the I-94 corridor freezing rain in the evening changed to rain overnight as warmer air was transported north into the region. Approximately 5 to 8 inches of new snow fell north of a Muskegon to Mount Pleasant line by early Tuesday morning.||Another upper disturbance approached Southwest Lower Michigan during the day of Tuesday the 9th while a cold front moved slowly southeast across the area. Many areas saw a change from rain or freezing rain to snow immediately behind the front. However, this snow only lasted a couple hours at most spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to eight inches of snow along with a little bit of sleet and freezing rain was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system produced very windy conditions across southwestern lower Michigan on December the 28th.  The highest wind gusts occurred mainly before sunrise, however very gusty conditions persisted well into the afternoon.  Hundreds of thousands of people across the state lost power at least temporarily due to high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated at 60 mph were recorded in Ottawa county.  Several trees and power lines were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer eight miles southwest of Ontonagon measured 11 inches of snow in the 24-hour period ending at 7 am on the 15th. West winds gusting over 30 mph caused reduced visibility in blowing snow as well. Schools were closed in Ontonagon on the 15th due to the harsh winter conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chills reported by the Houghton County Airport ASOS were around 25 below zero on the morning of the 16th. The Houghton-Keweenaw County Schools were on a two-hour delay.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observations indicated wind chill values of 20 to 25 below zero across much of the county during the morning of the 16th.  Keweenaw County Schools were on a two-hour delay.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer ten miles south of Grand Marais measured inches of snow in less than 18 hours. Northwest winds gusting over 30 mph at times also caused considerable blowing of snow and reduced visibilities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer near the Alger County measured eight inches of snow during the event. Northwest winds gusting over 30 mph caused considerable blowing of snow and reduced visibilities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values hovered around 25 below zero on the morning of the 16th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant low level moisture trapped under drier air aloft resulted in periods of widespread dense fog across portions of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 2nd through the morning of the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread dense fog reported throughout the county.

A low pressure system brought approximately four to eight inches of snow to portions of the area on one of the busiest travel days of the year during the latter portion of the Thanksgiving holiday weekend. Snow began on November the 30th and continued into December the first before gradually ending.||Snowfall amounts were quite variable across relatively small areas, possibly due to differences in surface temperatures, the frequency of measurements, or how sheltered the location was. The snow fell when temperatures were above freezing, which frequently resulted in melting or settling as soon as the snow hit the ground.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to eight inches of snow was reported in a twelve hour time frame.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought approximately four to eight inches of snow to portions of the area on one of the busiest travel days of the year during the latter portion of the Thanksgiving holiday weekend. The snow fell when temperatures were above freezing, which frequently resulted in melting or settling as soon as the snow hit the ground.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Anywhere from four to as much as eight inches of snow was reported in a twelve hour period across Montcalm county.  A trained spotter one mile northwest of Greenville reported a storm total of seven inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow impacted the lakeshore counties of west Michigan as north northwest flow over relatively warm waters of Lake Superior and Michigan resulted in lake effect snow.  Up to a foot of snow was reported across portions of Van Buren county, and there were several reports of seven to ten inches of snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter in Ludington reported that eight inches of snow fell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold northwest winds moving across the relatively warm waters of Lake Michigan, produced locally heavy lake effect snow in parts of Northern Lower Michigan.  Six to eight inches of snow fell in Alba, Mancelona, and between Elmira and Boyne City, on the night of the 16th.

Cold northwest winds moving across the relatively warm waters of Lake Michigan, produced locally heavy lake effect snow in parts of Northern Lower Michigan.  Six to eight inches of snow fell in Alba, Mancelona, and between Elmira and Boyne City, on the night of the 16th.
Abundant low level moisture trapped under drier air aloft resulted in periods of widespread dense fog across portions of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 2nd through the morning of the 4th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought approximately four to eight inches of snow to portions of the area on one of the busiest travel days of the year during the latter portion of the Thanksgiving holiday weekend. Snow began on November the 30th and continued into December the first before gradually ending.||Snowfall amounts were quite variable across relatively small areas, possibly due to differences in surface temperatures, the frequency of measurements, or how sheltered the location was. The snow fell when temperatures were above freezing, which frequently resulted in melting or settling as soon as the snow hit the ground.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Anywhere from four to as much as eight inches of snow was reported in a twelve hour period across Gratiot county.  A county official six miles east of Crystal reported that seven inches of snow fell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another in a series of lake effect snow events resulted in snowfall totals in excess of ten inches across portions of Ottawa and Allegan counties. Some of the heaviest snowfall also reached western Kent county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter in Wayland reported nearly nine inches of snow fell.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters across Ottawa county reported anywhere from six to ten inches of snow fell and that snowfall rates of an inch per hour occurred at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms marched across Eastern Upper Michigan early in the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a large pine tree just outside the administration building of Tahquamenon Falls State Park.  The tree was blasted into pieces, and most of the electronic equipment in the admin building was destroyed.  Some electrical damage also occurred in a staff building, not quite an eighth of a mile away.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broken line of strong thunderstorms developed over Lake Michigan, and then moved into Northwest Lower Michigan late in the evening on the 30th.  One storm produced quarter sized hail.

Low pressure moved across central Indiana during during the evening hours of the 25th into much of the 26th with widespread snow across far southern Lower Michigan. In general 5 to 7 inches of snow fell across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to seven inches of snow fell across the county.

A winter storm brought six to seven inches of snow to much of west central lower Michigan including Pentwater and Ludington. Lighter snow amounts were recorded further southeast of that area in Muskegon and Grand Rapids, where mixed precipitation resulted in ligher snow amounts.

A low pressure system brought heavy snow to much of southwestern lower Michigan from the 21st through the 22nd.  Snow began during the morning hours of the 21st and continued into the early morning hours of the 22nd before gradually diminishing.  ||The heaviest snow fell during the afternoon and early evening hours of the 21st, when snowfall rates of two inches per hour were reported at some locations.  The highest snowfall totals were received from Allegan, Van Buren and Kalamazoo counties, where over a foot of snow was reported at some locations.  Eight to fourteen inches of snow fell south of a line from Holland to Jackson.

Low pressure tracking from Missouri into Lower Michigan spread wet heavy snow across central and eastern Upper Michigan on the afternoon and evening of the 17th. Lake effect snow showers developing behind the storm added a few more inches to snow totals over the north central Lake Superior snowbelts into the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Germfask reported 12 inches of total snowfall. Numerous accidents were reported by law enforcement officials due to snowpacked and slippery roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful Arctic cold front pushed through the Upper Great Lakes on the afternoon and evening of the 9th and produced blizzard conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow over portions of Upper Michigan into the 10th. Bitterly cold wind chills of 30 below to 40 below zero were observed over much of Upper Michigan from the night of the 9th into the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures of zero to 10 below zero combined with wind gusts over 35 mph at times to produce wind chills between 25 below and 35 below zero across the county on the 10th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful Arctic cold front pushed through the Upper Great Lakes on the afternoon and evening of the 9th and produced blizzard conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow over portions of Upper Michigan into the 10th. Bitterly cold wind chills of 30 below to 40 below zero were observed over much of Upper Michigan from the night of the 9th into the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusting over 35 mph at times caused occasional whiteout conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow, especially along and north of Highway 28. Wind chills also lowered to 20 below zero on the 10th. Snowfall amounts of four to five inches were reported throughout the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another low pressure system approaching from the Plains spread heavy snow into portions of Delta and southern Schoolcraft on the morning of the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Garden Corners measured six inches of snow on the morning of the 14th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracking from Missouri into Lower Michigan spread wet heavy snow across central and eastern Upper Michigan on the afternoon and evening of the 17th. Lake effect snow showers developing behind the storm added a few more inches to snow totals over the north central Lake Superior snowbelts into the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in Stonington and Gladstone reported ten inches of wet heavy snow in the 12-hour period ending early evening on the 17th. Escanaba Public Safety asked residents not to drive unless it was an emergency as plows in the area were not able to keep up with the snowfall. Several vehicles were stuck on snowpacked roads and had to be towed away. Numerous accidents were reported by law enforcement.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread 8 to 12 inches of snow was reported across southern Schoolcraft County on the 17th. Numerous accidents were reported by law enforcement officials.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Northerly winds moving down the length of Lake Michigan resulted in a significant single band of lake effect snow Tuesday night into Wednesday morning. The heaviest total fell in teh southwest part of the county. The single band actually began north of the Upper Peninsula of Michigan in Lake Superior and stretched over 500 miles into Cass County Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The most intense part of a strong lake effect snow band remained west of Berrien county. However, far southwestern parts were not completely spared with a few spots picking up 6 to 9 inches of snow...mainly west of Buchanan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fairly short duration heavy rain event came to an end during the early morning hours of April first.  There were numerous reports of twenty four hour rainfall totals ranging from an inch to a little over two inches. The heavy rain did not result in any injuries or fatalities, but there were reports that several basements were flooded in Breckenridge.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain occurred in Breckenridge, resulting in water covering many fields.  Several homes had standing water in their yards and there were several reports of flooded basements. The storm total rainfall causing this minor flooding was one and sixty six hundredths of an inch, ending at  6:40 a.m. on April the first.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall and snowmelt on March 31st and April 1st contributed to minor flooding on the Rifle River.  Rainfall of around an inch was enough to push the river into the campgroun of White's Canoe Livery, near Sterling.  Damage was negligible.

Around an inch of rain fell in Eastern Upper Michigan on the night of the 8th into the morning of the 9th.  Coming at the end of a period of rapid snowmelt, the rain pushed the Pine River out of its banks near Rudyard.  At crest, the river level reached the bottom of the Prairie Road Bridge.
A dust devil destroyed a bird feeder, and sucked an inch of water out of a backyard pond.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a power pole and ignited a fire at a home in Negaunee on the evening of the 17th. The lightning bolt traveled from the power pole to a metal dryer vent on the side of the house, starting the fire. Negaunee firefighters responded to the blaze and all people inside the house escaped without injury.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a power pole outside a residence in Negaunee.  The lightning bolt traveled into the residence igniting a fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak and short lived EF-0 tornado struck Clare county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service storm survey confirmed that a small and brief tornado touched down in Clare county early in the morning of July 30.  The tornado was rated an EF-0 on the Enhanced Fujita Scale with maximum winds estimated at 80 mph.  ||The tornado occurred about three miles north of Clare at 3:17 a.m. A |barn collapsed and the roof of a carport was blown into a stand of trees. Several other trees were either snapped off or uprooted.   ||The tornado touched down just northwest of the intersection of South Clare Avenue and East Surrey Road and traveled east northeast about 2,000 feet before lifting. The width of the tornado was only 50 yards and it was on the ground for only about a minute.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system originating over the Plains deepened as it moved into the Western Great Lakes on March 31st. Snow mixed with rain and sleet over east and south central counties of Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 31st and then fell heavy at times through the evening of March 31st into April 1st. ||The combination of heavy snow and north winds gusting as high as 50 mph near the Lake Superior shore lead to blizzard conditions as well as numerous power outages over Marquette and Alger counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow began on the evening of the 31st and continued into the morning of April 1st. Storm total snowfall amounts of six to nine inches were reported across Keweenaw County ending on the morning of the 1st. North winds gusting over 30 mph at times also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow.

A vigorous low pressure system brought a round of moderate to heavy snow and strong winds to lower Michigan, resulting in blizzard to near blizzard conditions at times during the late evening and overnight hours.  The heaviest snowfall was reported mainly near and west of US-131 to the lakeshore, where around 4 to 7 inches of snow was reported. High winds accompanied the snow resulting in blizzard to near blizzard conditions overnight.||Storm impacts included very dangerous travel conditions during the late evening and overnight hours due to near zero visibility at times in snow and blowing snow.  Travel conditions remained treacherous during the morning hours of the 30th as a result of icy roads and blowing snow.  In fact over 500 schools were closed on the 30th due to icy roads and blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow moved into southern lower Michigan on New Year's Eve lasting into New Year's Day, impacting travel plans by creating very hazardous travel conditions in heavy snow and snow covered roads. Many locations across southern Michigan reported total snowfall of 7 to 10 inches, with as much as 11.5 inches reported three miles south southeast of Jackson. The snow gradually ended during the early morning hours on New Year's Day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful Arctic cold front pushed through the Upper Great Lakes on the afternoon and evening of the 9th and produced blizzard conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow over portions of Upper Michigan into the 10th. Bitterly cold wind chills of 30 below to 40 below zero were observed over much of Upper Michigan from the night of the 9th into the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures of 5 below to 10 below zero combined with wind gusts over 30 mph at times to drive wind chills down as low as 35 below zero.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful Arctic cold front pushed through the Upper Great Lakes on the afternoon and evening of the 9th and produced blizzard conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow over portions of Upper Michigan into the 10th. Bitterly cold wind chills of 30 below to 40 below zero were observed over much of Upper Michigan from the night of the 9th into the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures of zero to 10 below zero combined with wind gusts over 35 mph at times to produce wind chills between 25 below and 35 below zero across the county on the 10th. Although winds subsided by the evening of the 10th...actual temperatures fell to around 10 below zero during the early morning of the 11th resulting in wind chills near 25 below zero.  AAA Michigan reportedly responded to numerous motorists' calls of dead batteries or fuel line freezes during the cold weather.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures of 5 to 10 below zero combined with wind gusts over 35 mph at times to produce wind chills between 25 below and 35 below zero across the county on the 10th. Although winds subsided by the evening of the 10th...actual temperatures fell to around 10 below zero during the early morning of the 11th with wind chills near 30 below zero.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains low pressure system moved through the Lower Great Lakes and brought up to five inches of snow to portions of Delta and southern Schoolcraft counties on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five inches of snow fell at Garden Corners and Parent Bay on the morning of the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five inches of snow fell at Cooks on the morning of the 11th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains low pressure system spread moderate snow across portions of southern and eastern Upper Michigan on the 13th and 14th. Heavy lake effect snow also developed over Gogebic County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported around five inches of total snowfall in Stephenson and Menominee.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow moved into southern lower Michigan on New Year's Eve lasting into New Year's Day, impacting travel plans by creating very hazardous travel conditions in heavy snow and snow covered roads. Many locations across southern Michigan reported total snowfall of 7 to 10 inches, with as much as 11.5 inches reported three miles south southeast of Jackson. The snow gradually ended during the early morning hours on New Year's Day.

The snow gradually ended during the early morning hours on New Year's Day.

A rare mid winter severe weather event occurred and resulted in several reports of high winds and large hail.  There were few reports of damage associated with the severe weather.  However hail did briefly cover the ground near Mt. Pleasant, and one tree was blown down just southeast of Spring Arbor.  Two funnel clouds were also reported near Mt. Pleasant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An amateur radio operator reported one inch diameter hail 3 miles west of Howard City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted north through Southeast Lower Michigan, which resulted in a burst of heavy snow tapering off to light freezing rain. Parts of Saginaw and Tuscola counties received 4 inches of snow in a six hour period, with accumulations less everywhere else.

A warm front lifted north through Southeast Lower Michigan, which resulted in a burst of heavy snow tapering off to light freezing rain. Parts of Saginaw and Tuscola counties received 4 inches of snow in a six hour period, with accumulations less everywhere else.

A major winter storm tracking through the Ohio Valley just missed most of southeast Michigan to the east. Lake Enhancement off Lake Huron did help the Port Huron receive up to 7 inches of snow, along with strong northerly winds which allowed to blowing and drifting of snow, causing several cars to end up in ditches.

A low pressure system brought heavy snow to much of southwestern lower Michigan from the 21st through the 22nd.  Snow began during the morning hours of the 21st and continued into the early morning hours of the 22nd before gradually diminishing.  ||The heaviest snow fell during the afternoon and early evening hours of the 21st, when snowfall rates of two inches per hour were reported at some locations.  The highest snowfall totals were received from Allegan, Van Buren and Kalamazoo counties, where over a foot of snow was reported at some locations.  Eight to fourteen inches of snow fell south of a line from Holland to Jackson.

A low pressure system brought heavy snow to much of southwestern lower Michigan from the 21st through the 22nd.  Snow began during the morning hours of the 21st and continued into the early morning hours of the 22nd before gradually diminishing.  ||The heaviest snow fell during the afternoon and early evening hours of the 21st, when snowfall rates of two inches per hour were reported at some locations.  The highest snowfall totals were received from Allegan, Van Buren and Kalamazoo counties, where over a foot of snow was reported at some locations.  Eight to fourteen inches of snow fell south of a line from Holland to Jackson.

A vigorous low pressure system brought a round of moderate to heavy snow and strong winds to lower Michigan, resulting in blizzard to near blizzard conditions at times during the late evening and overnight hours.  The heaviest snowfall was reported mainly near and west of US-131 to the lakeshore, where around 4 to 7 inches of snow was reported. High winds accompanied the snow resulting in blizzard to near blizzard conditions overnight.||Storm impacts included very dangerous travel conditions during the late evening and overnight hours due to near zero visibility at times in snow and blowing snow.  Travel conditions remained treacherous during the morning hours of the 30th as a result of icy roads and blowing snow.  In fact over 500 schools were closed on the 30th due to icy roads and blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers occurred over portions of  central Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A foot or more of snow was reported over sparsely populated sections of northern Delta County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake-Effect snow squalls and showers affected much of far northwest Indiana and southwest lower Michigan November 17th into very early November 18th. This was a result of arctic air overriding warm lake waters behind a strong cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported a snowfall total of 5.8 in Niles, MI.  The bulk of the snow fell late November 17th into the first half of November 18th as a single lake-effect band (Type 3 Lake Event Snow) set up over Berrien County.  The snow created icy roads with a few reports of traffic accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought approximately four to eight inches of snow to portions of the area on one of the busiest travel days of the year during the latter portion of the Thanksgiving holiday weekend. Snow began on November the 30th and continued into December the first before gradually ending. ||Snowfall amounts were quite variable across relatively small areas, possibly due to differences in surface temperatures, the frequency of measurements, or how sheltered the location was. The snow fell when temperatures were above freezing, which frequently resulted in melting or settling as soon as the snow hit the ground.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to as much as eight inches of snow was reported in a twelve hour period across Ottawa county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to as much as eight inches of snow was reported in a twelve hour period across Kenty county.  A little over seven inches of snow was reported by a trained spotter in Byron Center.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold northwesterly winds crossed relatively warm Lake Michigan waters early November 20th.  This resulted in lake-effect snow, with an intense single band (Type 3 Lake Effect Snow event) that set up over Berrien County and western Cass County late on November 20th into the first half of November 21st.  Amounts of 8-14 inches were reported within this heavy lake effect snow band.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An intense single lake-effect band set up over Berrien County late November 20th into November 21st. Snowfall reports ranged between 8 and 14 inches, with 13.5 at Benton Harbor, 11.0 at Stevensville, 8.9 at Niles, and 8.5 at Buchanan. Several slide-offs and some accidents were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold northwesterly winds crossed relatively warm Lake Michigan waters early November 20th.  This resulted in lake-effect snow, with an intense single band (Type 3 Lake Effect Snow event) that set up over Berrien County and western Cass County late on November 20th into the first half of November 21st.  Amounts of 8-14 inches were reported within this heavy lake effect snow band.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An intense single lake-effect band set up over Cass County November 20th and continued into very early November 21st. The heaviest snowfall reports were across the western half of the county, with 10 of snow accumulation reported just northwest of Dowagiac. Several slide-offs and some accidents were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Negaunee man drowned while swimming near Picnic Rocks in Marquette at 4:34 pm on the 10th. A strong low pressure system brought snow to the Northern Great Lakes region.  Locally heavy snow developed in parts of Northwest Lower Michigan on the evening of the 30th, with Lake Ann picking up 13 inches of snow by morning of the 1st.  However, for most of the region, the heaviest snow fell on the 1st.  Thus, a more complete disucssion of this event will be contained in Storm Data for December 2008.

A northerly flow of colder air across Lake Superior in the wake of an Alberta clipper system brought heavy lake snow to portions of central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 19th through the evening of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Manistique reported an estimated 12-hour snowfall amount of 8 inches with a storm total amount of 13 inches. There was also a public report of 5 to 6 inches in 12 hours at Germfask on the morning of the 21st. The heavy snow forced the closure of Manistique area schools on the 21st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers occurred over portions of  central Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of one half inch to inch an hour snowfall rates from lake effect snow.  Between Munising and Shingleton four inch snowfall amounts were common.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers occurred over portions of  central Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between McMillan and Helmer 12-hour snowfall amounts of 5 to 6 inches were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought approximately four to eight inches of snow to portions of the area on one of the busiest travel days of the year during the latter portion of the Thanksgiving holiday weekend. Snow began on November the 30th and continued into December the first before gradually ending.||Snowfall amounts were quite variable across relatively small areas, possibly due to differences in surface temperatures, the frequency of measurements, or how sheltered the location was. The snow fell when temperatures were above freezing, which frequently resulted in melting or settling as soon as the snow hit the ground.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to as much as eight inches of snow was reported in a twelve hour period across Ottawa county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid November early season lake effect snow event developed and resulted in total snow amounts of up to nine to ten inches across portions of Ottawa, Allegan and Van Buren counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to nine inches of snow was reported across portions of Ottawa county. A trained spotter reported nine inches of snow four miles north of Holland and the public reported 7.5 inches of snow 3 miles northwest of Holland.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to ten inches of snow fell across portions of Van Buren county.

A clipper low pressure system moved through the Northern Great Lakes region on the 6th.  Southwest winds ahead of the clipper kicked off heavy lake enhanced snow near Lake Michigan, beginning late on the 5th.  As the clipper passed, another burst of heavy snow moved through, with a period of gusty northwest winds and resulting blowing and drifting snow.  Fourteen inches of snow fell in Epoufette, while most of Leelanau and Benzie Counties had around 10 inches of snow from this event.
Southwest flow across Lake Michigan produced lake enhanced snow over portions of Luce County on the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow totals over a 12-hour period included 7 inches in Newberry and 10 inches at Rainbow Lodge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northerly flow of colder air across Lake Superior in the wake of an Alberta clipper system brought heavy lake snow to portions of central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 19th through the evening of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals during this period included 10 inches near Ishpeming and Carlshend, 14 inches in Negaunee and 17 inches at the National Weather Service in Negaunee Township.  ||Several schools were closed in Marquette County on the 20th due to the poor road conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northerly flow of colder air across Lake Superior in the wake of an Alberta clipper system brought heavy lake snow to portions of central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 19th through the evening of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snow accumulation during the lake effect snow event included more than a foot of snow at both Rock and Cornell and 20 inches just northwest of Gladstone. The heavy snow forced the closure of schools in Escanaba and Gladstone on the 21st.

A clipper low pressure system moved through the Northern Great Lakes region on the 6th.  Southwest winds ahead of the clipper kicked off heavy lake enhanced snow near Lake Michigan, beginning late on the 5th.  As the clipper passed, another burst of heavy snow moved through, with a period of gusty northwest winds and resulting blowing and drifting snow.  Fourteen inches of snow fell in Epoufette, while most of Leelanau and Benzie Counties had around 10 inches of snow from this event.

Locally moderate to heavy lake effect snow fell over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 8th through the morning of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter five miles north of Shingleton reported 12 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers occurred over portions of  central Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals during this period included 22 inches at Trenary, 12 inches at Eben Junction and 11 inches near Chatham.

A northerly flow of colder air across Lake Superior in the wake of an Alberta clipper system brought heavy lake snow to portions of central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 19th through the evening of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall through the lake effect snow event included 12  inches near Chatham and 24 inches at Shingleton. Two to three inch per hour snowfall rates were reported at times from the intense lake effect snow bands. Several schools in Alger County were canceled on the 20th due to the poor road conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northerly flow of colder air across Lake Superior in the wake of an Alberta clipper system brought heavy lake snow to portions of central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 19th through the evening of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: South of Shingleton along the Alger County border...storm total snowfall was estimated at 12 to 18 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Locally moderate to heavy lake effect snow fell over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 8th through the morning of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported 12 inches of snow near the northwest portion of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were reported by the Houghton County Airport ASOS from 9 am to 3 pm with visibility below one-quarter mile and frequent wind gusts of 35 mph or greater.||Houghton County schools were closed on the 15th due to the blizzard conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system tracked northeast from northern Lake Michigan, sending a strong cold front through southeast Michigan. Winds gusts of 50 to 65 mph behind the cold front lead to widespread tree branches and trees downed, along with extensive power outages, as more than 400,000 Michigan homes and businesses lost power. The majority of those customers who lost power were located in the Detroit Metro Area.

Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated lake effect snow amounts of six to eight inches occurred over portions of northern Luce County during the event. West winds gusting over 30 mph also caused considerable blowing of snow and reduced visibility. Tahquamenon Area Schools were closed on the 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Ironwood AWOS reported wind chill values between 25 and 35 below zero through the period. Temperatures plunged into the 15 to 20 below zero range across much of the county on the morning of the 16th as schools closed in Ironwood, Wakefield and Watersmeet-Marenisco.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front blasted portions of Upper Michigan with blizzard to near-blizzard conditions and occasional heavy snow on the 6th and 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Occasional visibilities less than one-quarter mile were reported at Mohawk as winds gusted between 30-35 mph across much of the county. The Copper Harbor ASOS reported a few wind gusts to 45 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front blasted portions of Upper Michigan with blizzard to near-blizzard conditions and occasional heavy snow on the 6th and 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Ironwood Police reported an estimated foot of lake effect snow at some places across the city. Wind gusts to 30 mph also caused blowing and drifting of snow with visibilities of less than one-quarter mile at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper wave tracked through southern Lower Michigan, with the associated surface low track through northern Ohio. This track helped lock in the cold air in place, resulting in a general 6 to 12 inch snowfall across southeast Michigan, which fell in a ten hour period. Here are some of the higher snowfall totals reported:||Flint (Genessee) 7.4 inches. |Clio  (Genessee) 11.0 inches.|Port Austin (Huron) 10.0 inches. |Harbor Beach (Huron) 10.0 inches.|Elba (Lapeer) 8.0 inches.|Lapeer (Lapeer) 9.3 inches.|Brighton (Livingson) 9.0 inches.|Shelby Township (Macomb) 11.5 inches.|Sterling Heights (Macomb) 10.0 inches.|Midland (Midland) 10.5 inches. |Maybee (Monroe) 6.0 inches. |Lake Orion (Oakland) 12.0 inches.|Rochester Hills 11.5 inches.|Burt (Saginaw) 12.0 inches.|Saginaw (Saginaw) 11.0 inches. |Marlette (Sanilac) 12.8 inches.|Port Huron (St. Clair) 11.0 inches. |Fairgrove (Tuscola) 11.0 inches.|Ann Arbor (Washtenaw) 7.2 inches. |Wyandotte (Wayne) 8.5 inches.

An Alberta Clipper tracked southeastward through the southern Great Lakes on Saturday December 6th. There were light snow accumulations of an inch or two from the morning into the early afternoon hours. Colder northwest winds filtered in behind this clipper, which led to multiple lake effect snow shower bands across southwestern Lower Michigan late Saturday afternoon through early Sunday morning the 7th. Snowfall amounts of 5-8 were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light snow developed ahead of an Alberta Clipper early Saturday morning and continued into Saturday afternoon. Lake-effect snow showers developed behind the clipper, with snowfall totals from the event ranging between 2 and 6 inches. There was a 24 hour report of 5.5 at Bronson. The fallen snow, plus blowing and drifting snow with reduced visibilities, led to icy road conditions with a few accidents reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta Clipper tracked southeastward through the southern Great Lakes on Saturday December 6th. There were light snow accumulations of an inch or two from the morning into the early afternoon hours. Colder northwest winds filtered in behind this clipper, which led to multiple lake effect snow shower bands across southwestern Lower Michigan late Saturday afternoon through early Sunday morning the 7th. Snowfall amounts of 5-8 were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light snow developed ahead of an Alberta Clipper early Saturday morning and continued into Saturday afternoon. Lake-effect snow showers developed behind the clipper, with snowfall totals from the event ranging between 3 and 7 inches. There was a CoCoRaHS report of 6.2 just northwest of Dowagiac. The fallen snow, plus blowing and drifting snow with reduced visibilities, led to icy road conditions with a few accidents reported.

A low pressure system tracked through southeast Michigan, delivering 5 to 9 inches of snow north of I-69, with amounts quickly tapering off farther south as precipitation type was mostly rain. |Here are some of the higher snowfall totals reported:|Auburn (Bay) 8 inches.|Filion (Huron) 7.3 inches.|Hope (Midland) 9 inches.|Freeland (Saginaw) 7 inches.|Caro (Tuscola) 6.7 inches.
An intense clipper low descending from southern Canada brought high winds...snow and blowing snow to areas along Lake Superior on the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Northwest winds gusting over 40 mph at times lowered visibility to one half mile or less in lake effect snow and blowing snow during the afternoon and evening of the 29th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense clipper low descending from southern Canada brought high winds...snow and blowing snow to areas along Lake Superior on the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Northwest winds gusted between 50 to 60 mph at the GLOS site at Grand Marais on the afternoon of the 29th, while winds gusted over 40 mph at the Munising ASOS. Light snow and reduced visibility in blowing snow were also reported by several spotters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense clipper low descending from southern Canada brought high winds...snow and blowing snow to areas along Lake Superior on the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Northwest winds gusting over 40 mph reduced visibility to one half mile or less in snow and blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta Clipper tracked southeastward through the southern Great Lakes on Saturday December 6th. There were light snow accumulations of an inch or two from the morning into the early afternoon hours. Colder northwest winds filtered in behind this clipper, which led to multiple lake effect snow shower bands across southwestern Lower Michigan late Saturday afternoon through early Sunday morning the 7th. Snowfall amounts of 5-8 were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow fell Saturday into Saturday night, with snowfall totals of 4 to 8 inches reported across the county. Buchanan reported 8, while 7.1 were reported in Niles. The fallen snow, plus blowing and drifting snow with reduced visibilities, led to icy road conditions with a few accidents reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick moving low pressure system tracked eastward through the northern Ohio Valley early December 19th. Precipitation broke out to the north of this system, with snow mixing with freezing rain and sleet across much of southwestern Lower Michigan. Most locations received between 2 and 6 inches of snow, with up to a quarter inch of ice accumulation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow developed early December 19th and continued through the bulk of the morning hours. The snow mixed with freezing rain and sleet at times, with trace ice amounts reported. A trained spotter just east of Jonesville reported 6 inches of snow accumulation.

A clipper low pressure system moving through Wisconsin brought heavy lake enhanced snow to portions of Delta County on the 20th and 21st. The system also brought heavy lake effect snow to portions of Marquette County and the Keweenaw Peninsula. Winds gusting around 40 mph at times also caused considerable blowing of snow over the Keweenaw Peninsula.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer along Highway M-35 near the Menominee County line measured 8.6 inches of lake enhanced snow in the 12-hour period ending on the morning of the 21st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper low pressure system moving through Wisconsin brought heavy lake enhanced snow to portions of Delta County on the 20th and 21st. The system also brought heavy lake effect snow to portions of Marquette County and the Keweenaw Peninsula. Winds gusting around 40 mph at times also caused considerable blowing of snow over the Keweenaw Peninsula.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Ahmeek measured eight inches of lake effect snow in the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 22nd.  Winds gusted to 30 mph at times causing considerable blowing and drifting of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper low pressure system moving through Wisconsin brought heavy lake enhanced snow to portions of Delta County on the 20th and 21st. The system also brought heavy lake effect snow to portions of Marquette County and the Keweenaw Peninsula. Winds gusting around 40 mph at times also caused considerable blowing of snow over the Keweenaw Peninsula.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind chill temperature plummeted to 25 to 30 below zero in Ironwood on the morning of the 22nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air filtered into southwest lower Michigan behind a strong cold front early on December 21st. Westerly winds in excess of 35 mph, combined with heavy lake-effect snow showers led to zero to a quarter mile visibility for extended periods of time December 21st into early December 22nd. The limited visibility led to a 100-vehicle crash on I-94 in Berrien County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake-effect snow squalls combined with frequent wind gusts in excess of 40 mph produced blizzard conditions across Cass County, especially during the afternoon and evening hours on December 21st. A trained spotter near Cassopolis reported white out conditions due to high winds and snow showers. Many roads were impassable due to 3 to 5 foot high snow drifts. Snowfall amounts were generally between 3 and 8 inches, although far northwest Cass County received nearly a foot of snow.

A clipper low pressure system moving through Wisconsin brought heavy lake enhanced snow to portions of Delta County on the 20th and 21st. The system also brought heavy lake effect snow to portions of Marquette County and the Keweenaw Peninsula. Winds gusting around 40 mph at times also caused considerable blowing of snow over the Keweenaw Peninsula.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in Toivola measured 6 inches of snow in 7 hours on the 21st.  Northwest winds gusting to 25 to 30 mph at the Houghton County Airport occasionally lowered visibility to one half mile through the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick moving low pressure system tracked eastward through the northern Ohio Valley early December 19th. Precipitation broke out to the north of this system, with snow mixing with freezing rain and sleet across much of southwestern Lower Michigan. Most locations received between 2 and 6 inches of snow, with up to a quarter inch of ice accumulation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow developed early December 19th and continued through the bulk of the morning hours. The snow mixed with freezing rain and sleet at times, with ice accumulations in excess of a tenth of an inch on trees and power lines. A trained spotter also reported nearly 2 inches of snow and sleet in White Pigeon. The sleet, snow, and freezing rain led to icy road conditions with reports of slide-offs and accidents around the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick moving low pressure system tracked eastward through the northern Ohio Valley early December 19th. Precipitation broke out to the north of this system, with snow mixing with freezing rain and sleet across much of southwestern Lower Michigan. Most locations received between 2 and 6 inches of snow, with up to a quarter inch of ice accumulation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow developed early December 19th and continued through the bulk of the morning hours. The snow mixed with freezing rain and sleet at times, with some icing reported on trees and power lines. There were reports of nearly 3 to 4 inches of snow near Dowagiac. The sleet, snow, and freezing rain led to icy road conditions with reports of slide-offs and accidents around the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain blanketed portions of southwest Lower Michigan with a thin sheet of ice during the morning hours of December 26th. Precipitation developed ahead of an approaching warm front, with temperatures generally in the mid to upper 20s as the freezing rain developed. Surface temperatures warmed above freezing by late in the morning, which changed the precipitation over to rain and drizzle. Numerous accidents and slide-offs were reported across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of freezing rain and freezing drizzle led to icy roadways and numerous accidents during the morning hours of December 26th. Lanes on Interstate 69 were closed at times due to the slippery conditions. Ice accumulations were generally less than 0.20 across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain blanketed portions of southwest Lower Michigan with a thin sheet of ice during the morning hours of December 26th. Precipitation developed ahead of an approaching warm front, with temperatures generally in the mid to upper 20s as the freezing rain developed. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of freezing rain and freezing drizzle led to icy roadways and numerous accidents during the morning hours of December 26th. Ice accumulations were generally less than 0.20 across the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow developed early December 19th and continued through the bulk of the morning hours. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air filtered into southwest lower Michigan behind a strong cold front early on December 21st. Westerly winds in excess of 35 mph, combined with heavy lake-effect snow showers led to zero to a quarter mile visibility for extended periods of time December 21st into early December 22nd. The limited visibility led to a 100-vehicle crash on I-94 in Berrien County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake-effect snow squalls combined with frequent wind gusts in excess of 40 mph produced blizzard conditions across Berrien County, especially during the afternoon and evening hours on December 21st. Trained spotters across the county reported between 5 and 11 inches of snow, with 6 inches at Niles and 11 inches near Eau Claire. The media reported a 100 car pile-up on I-94 around 06:00 pm near Stevensville due to visibilities near zero. A 31 year old man was killed in the pile-up when his vehicle struck a stopped semi truck.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper wave tracked through southern Lower Michigan, with the associated surface low track through northern Ohio. This track helped lock in the cold air in place, resulting in a general 6 to 12 inch snowfall across southeast Michigan, which fell in a ten hour period. Here are some of the higher snowfall totals reported:||Flint (Genessee) 7.4 inches. |Clio  (Genessee) 11.0 inches.|Port Austin (Huron) 10.0 inches. |Harbor Beach (Huron) 10.0 inches.|Elba (Lapeer) 8.0 inches.|Lapeer (Lapeer) 9.3 inches.|Brighton (Livingson) 9.0 inches.|Shelby Township (Macomb) 11.5 inches.|Sterling Heights (Macomb) 10.0 inches.|Midland (Midland) 10.5 inches. |Maybee (Monroe) 6.0 inches. |Lake Orion (Oakland) 12.0 inches.|Rochester Hills 11.5 inches.|Burt (Saginaw) 12.0 inches.|Saginaw (Saginaw) 11.0 inches. |Marlette (Sanilac) 12.8 inches.|Port Huron (St. Clair) 11.0 inches. |Fairgrove (Tuscola) 11.0 inches.|Ann Arbor (Washtenaw) 7.2 inches. |Wyandotte (Wayne) 8.5 inches.
An intense clipper low descending from southern Canada brought high winds...snow and blowing snow to areas along Lake Superior on the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated between 50 and 60 mph downed a few trees near Two Heart on the afternoon of the 29th. Snow and blowing snow also reduced visibility to one half mile or less at times over northern Luce County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense single lake effect band developed off the relatively warm waters of Lake Michigan. The eastern part of Berrien County and all of Cass County experienced moderate to heavy snow for several hours with 3 to 5 inches of snow falling by the end of the event. The snowfall contributed to at least 2 accidents in Cass County, with 6 injuries occurring.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six people were treated for injuries in two separate accidents as a result of icy roads. A 32 year old male from Dowagiac was traveling south on Wilbur Hill Road in LaGrange Township, when he lost control of his vehicle at 1:45 p.m. His vehicle ran off the road and struck a tree. He was treated and released. Five people were treated for injuries from a three-vehicle accident on Marcellus Highway, just west of Atwood Road in Wayne Township at 430 pm. A 42 year old woman from Marcellus was driving on Marcellus Highway when she lost control of her vehicle. It crossed the center line and struck two other vehicles. ||A 62 year old female from Dowagiac, was driving the first vehicle struck. Cass County police say she was not injured. The second vehicle struck was driven by an 18 year old female from Dowagiac. She and two passengers were treated and released from Borgess Lee Memorial Hospital. Another 18 year old passenger in the first car was in critical condition at the time of the report.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense clipper low descending from southern Canada brought high winds...snow and blowing snow to areas along Lake Superior on the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Northwest winds gusting over 40 mph at times lowered visibility to one half mile or less in lake effect snow and blowing snow during the afternoon of the 29th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick moving low pressure system tracked eastward through the northern Ohio Valley early December 19th. Precipitation broke out to the north of this system, with snow mixing with freezing rain and sleet across much of southwestern Lower Michigan. Most locations received between 2 and 6 inches of snow, with up to a quarter inch of ice accumulation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow developed early December 19th and continued through the bulk of the morning hours. The snow mixed with freezing rain and sleet at times, with ice accumulations in excess of a tenth of an inch on trees and power lines. A trained spotter also reported nearly 3 inches of snow and sleet accumulation near Niles. The sleet, snow, and freezing rain led to icy road conditions with reports of slide-offs and accidents around the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracked through southeast Michigan, delivering 5 to 9 inches of snow north of I-69, with amounts quickly tapering off farther south as precipitation type was mostly rain. |Here are some of the higher snowfall totals reported:|Auburn (Bay) 8 inches.|Filion (Huron) 7.3 inches.|Hope (Midland) 9 inches.|Freeland (Saginaw) 7 inches.|Caro (Tuscola) 6.7 inches.
A deep low pressure system advancing from the central Plains brought a mix of snow...rain and some freezing rain to portions of Upper Michigan  on the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter five miles northwest of Wakefield estimated four to six inches of snow in 12 hours. Some freezing rain was also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep low pressure system advancing from the central Plains brought a mix of snow...rain and some freezing rain to portions of Upper Michigan  on the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A sloppy mix of wet snow and rain contributed to very slippery highways across the county on the 14th.  One car slid into a guardrail on Highway 41. The observer in Watton reported two inches of wet snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep low pressure system advancing from the central Plains brought a mix of snow...rain and some freezing rain to portions of Upper Michigan  on the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wintry mix of wet snow...rain and freezing rain contributed to very slippery driving conditions in the hills of Houghton/Hancock as reported by WLUC-TV in Marquette.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow occurred on December 6th, with areas west of US-131 being the hardest hit.  The combination of snow and blowing snow behind the Alberta clipper system caused very hazardous travel conditions. The wind direction was from the south southwest during the morning, which resulted in heavy snow falling north and west of a line from Holland to Reed City. Over a foot of snow piled up across portions of Newaygo and Mason counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to ten inches of snow and blowing snow was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow occurred on December 6th, with areas west of US-131 being the hardest hit.  The combination of snow and blowing snow behind the Alberta clipper system caused very hazardous travel conditions. The wind direction was from the south southwest during the morning, which resulted in heavy snow falling north and west of a line from Holland to Reed City. Over a foot of snow piled up across portions of Newaygo and Mason counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported four to eight inches of snow and blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved from Kansas City, Missouri to north of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Snow spread into southwest lower Michigan out ahead of the low, starting in South Haven at around 2:00 a.m. on the nineteenth. ||The snow quickly spread north and began in Mount Pleasant at around 4:30 a.m.  Heavy Snow occurred across most of the area between 5:00 a.m. and 1:00 pm, with snowfall rates reaching 1 to 2 inches per hour at times.  Thundersnow was even reported at locations across southern lower Michigan, evidence to the instability in place with this system.  ||Some sleet and freezing rain mixed in along the Interstate 94 corridor. The heaviest snow occurred in a swath from Pentwater south to Holland, east through Newaygo, Grand Rapids, Alma and St. John's. Another maximum of snow was found across south central lower Michigan from Bellevue in Eaton county southeast to Vandercook Lake in Jackson county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to nine inches of snow was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system produced very windy conditions across southwestern lower Michigan on December the 28th.  The highest wind gusts occurred mainly before sunrise, however very gusty conditions persisted well into the afternoon.  Hundreds of thousands of people across the state lost power at least temporarily due to high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated wind gusts reached 60 mph during the early morning hours of the 28th.  Several trees and power lines down.

Hundreds of thousands of people across the state lost power at least temporarily due to high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated wind gusts reached 60 mph during the early morning hours of the 28th. Numerous trees and power lines were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system produced very windy conditions across southwestern lower Michigan on December the 28th.  The highest wind gusts occurred mainly before sunrise, however very gusty conditions persisted well into the afternoon.  Hundreds of thousands of people across the state lost power at least temporarily due to high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured wind gust reached 60 mph eight miles north northwest of Ludington during the early morning hours of the 28th.  Several trees and power lines were blown down.
