EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Most of southwestern lower Michigan had a substantial snowpack on the ground on Christmas Day. Most if not all of that snowpack melted as a result of warm temperatures, high winds and rain after Christmas. Several locations received an inch and a half to two inches of rainfall, all of which fell in only a twenty four hour time period. The flooding caused well over three million dollars worth of damage across Ottawa county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding across portions of Ottawa county was a result of the combination of heavy rain and melting of a significant snowpack across the area.  There were up to 80 road closures and significant flooding of numerous intersections.  At one time a section of US-31 was closed.  Water up to four feet deep across some roads floated several cars. ||The road shoulder and pavement was washed out on several roads in Jamestown, Hudsonville and Conklin. Roads in several subdivisions across Ottawa county were submerged under two to three feet of water and there were reports of first floors of some homes being flooded. ||Severe flooding also occurred in the village of Spring Lake, city of Grand Haven and across Spring Lake and Robinson Townships as the result of back water from an ice jam on the Grand River in Grand Haven.   ||A damage assessment conducted by Ottawa county revealed that a total of $270,500 worth of damage occurred to public infrastructure, with a total of $3,292,400 worth of damage to private property. As a result of the widespread flooding, a local state of emergency was declared in Ottawa county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper low pressure system moving through Wisconsin brought heavy lake enhanced snow to portions of Delta County on the 20th and 21st. The system also brought heavy lake effect snow to portions of Marquette County and the Keweenaw Peninsula. Winds gusting around 40 mph at times also caused considerable blowing of snow over the Keweenaw Peninsula.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight inches of lake effect snow fell just north of Ishpeming in the 12-hour period ending on the morning of the 21st. Eight inches of snow also fell in Harvey for the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 22nd. Locally heavy snow and blowing snow continued from the 21st into the morning of the 22nd.

A stationary low pressure trough over central Lake Superior focused heavy lake effect snow showers over Keweenaw County on the 17th into the morning of the 18th. As the trough sagged slowly south...heavy lake effect snow then became focused over north central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 18th into the morning of 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter reports near Calumet ranged from 3 to 6 inches in 12 hours during the event.

A low pressure moving from the Plains toward the Lower Great Lakes on Christmas Eve spread moderate to heavy snow over portions of east and west Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters in the Munising-Wetmore area measured 6 to 7 inches of snow in less than 24 hours, while the spotter just south of Grand Marais measured nearly 9 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper wave tracked through southern Lower Michigan, with the associated surface low track through northern Ohio. This track helped lock in the cold air in place, resulting in a general 6 to 12 inch snowfall across southeast Michigan, which fell in a ten hour period. Here are some of the higher snowfall totals reported:||Flint (Genessee) 7.4 inches. |Clio  (Genessee) 11.0 inches.|Port Austin (Huron) 10.0 inches. |Harbor Beach (Huron) 10.0 inches.|Elba (Lapeer) 8.0 inches.|Lapeer (Lapeer) 9.3 inches.|Brighton (Livingson) 9.0 inches.|Shelby Township (Macomb) 11.5 inches.|Sterling Heights (Macomb) 10.0 inches.|Midland (Midland) 10.5 inches. |Maybee (Monroe) 6.0 inches. |Lake Orion (Oakland) 12.0 inches.|Rochester Hills 11.5 inches.|Burt (Saginaw) 12.0 inches.|Saginaw (Saginaw) 11.0 inches. |Marlette (Sanilac) 12.8 inches.|Port Huron (St. Clair) 11.0 inches. |Fairgrove (Tuscola) 11.0 inches.|Ann Arbor (Washtenaw) 7.2 inches. |Wyandotte (Wayne) 8.5 inches.

Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Ironwood measured eight inches of snow in the 24-hour period ending at 5 am on the 15th. West winds gusting over 30 mph also contributed to blowing snow and visibilities reduced to one-half mile at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed in the wake of a cold front and became heavy at times for the northwest wind snowbelts from the 3rd into the 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pine Stump Junction reported an estimated 15-16 inches of snow in less than 18 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep low pressure system advancing from the central Plains brought a mix of snow...rain and some freezing rain to portions of Upper Michigan  on the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Marquette National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured  over 4.5 inches of wet snow in 14 hours.  The mix of rain and snow contributed to slippery highways and a few minor accidents throughout the county on the 14th.  The poor weather conditions also forced airlines to cancel flights in and out of K.I. Sawyer International Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary low pressure trough over central Lake Superior focused heavy lake effect snow showers over Keweenaw County on the 17th into the morning of the 18th. As the trough sagged slowly south...heavy lake effect snow then became focused over north central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 18th into the morning of 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mohawk observer measured 12 inches in the 12-hour period ending at 830 am on the 18th and 16 inches in 24 hours. The Keweenaw County Sheriff in Eagle Harbor estimated 12 inches of snow in less 12 hours on the morning of the 18th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper low pressure system moving through Wisconsin brought heavy lake enhanced snow to portions of Delta County on the 20th and 21st. The system also brought heavy lake effect snow to portions of Marquette County and the Keweenaw Peninsula. Winds gusting around 40 mph at times also caused considerable blowing of snow over the Keweenaw Peninsula.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Keweenaw County Sheriff reported 6 inches of snow in 8 hours at Eagle Harbor from the evening of the 21st into the early morning of the 22nd. North winds gusting over 30 mph caused blowing and drifting of snow  throughout the day of the 22nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system tracking west of the area allowed temperatures to reach into the upper 50s to middle 60s, record highs for the date. A few severe storms, producing both wind and hail damage, occurred mainly along and west of U.S. 23 during the mid evening hours.

A strengthening low pressure system moved from the St Louis area toward Lake Huron.  Heavy snow occurred just left of the track of the low.  Accumulation rates of one to two inches per hour were common in the mid to late evening hours of the 10th, though these rates did not last long in any one place.  Accumulations were around six inches in a swath across Northwest and far Northern Lower Michigan.  The snow swath continued into Eastern Upper Michigan, with six to nine inches of snow along the I-75 corridor.  The highest snowfall amounts, from eight to nine inches, fell from Moran to Sault Ste Marie.

A low pressure system tracked very close to Downtown Detroit during the early morning hours of New Years Day. Heavy snow fell to the west and north of this track and fell steadily at a rate of 1 to 2 inches per hour from roughly midnight to 0700 EST across much of the area. An intense snow band did set up between the M-59 and I-69 corridors, where snowfall rates actually approached 4 inches per hour at times. Consequently, a swath of 12 to 16 inches of snow fell roughly from Brighton in south Livingston County to Lexington in southeast St Clair County. North and south of this area, snowfall amounts quickly tapered off. This storm will be most remembered for the amount of snow that fell in such a short period of time. The bulk of the snowfall, including the amounts over one foot, fell in less than 7 hours. Here are some of the higher snowfall reports received from each County.|Dryden (Lapeer) 16 inches.|Capac (St Clair) 16 inches.|Clarkston (Oakland) 15.5 inches.|Lexington (Sanilac) 12.3 inches.|Brighton (Livingston) 12.0 inches.|Ann Arbor (Washtenaw) 10.5 inches.|Grand Blanc (Genesee) 9.5 inches.|Cement City (Lenawee) 9.5 inches.|Armada (Macomb) 9.0 inches.|Plymouth (Wayne) 7.0 inches.|Marlette (Tuscola) 7.0 inches.|Owosso (Shiawassee) 6.2 inches.|Bridgeport (Saginaw) 5.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported 6 inches of snow over a 9 hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through southeast Michigan just before midnight, with strong post frontal wind gusts of 50 to 60 mph reported across much of area. The highest winds occurred across the Thumb region, extending south into the Detroit Metro area. A few buildings and houses sustained damage, mostly shingle and roof damage. |Trees and power lines were blown down, which led to power outages. Utility companies reported thousands of residents and businesses lost power due to downed power lines across the northern Thumb region, with close to 100,000 in the Lower Peninsula, with a majority of those outages occurring in southeast Michigan.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and limbs were brought down by the strong wind. A roof of a patio was also ripped off in Clarkston.

A low pressure system tracking from Wisconsin into eastern Upper Michigan brought widespread heavy snow to much of the region on the 17th and 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread snowfall of six to eight inches was reported by COOP observers throughout Delta County. Law enforcement officials reported numerous accidents in Escanaba and Gladstone to due snowpacked and slippery roadways. School closures from the snow included Big Bay De Noc, Escanaba Head Start, Bark River-Harris, Hannahville, Carney-Nadeau, Rapid River and Superior Central.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Wisconsin into eastern Upper Michigan brought widespread heavy snow to much of the region on the 17th and 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: COOP observers between Silver City and Ontonagon reported nine inches of snow in 12 hours and 16 inches over 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm, moist air moving over melting snowpack produced widespread dense fog across much of Upper Michigan from the 6th continuing into the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread dense fog was reported through much of this period.

Here are some of the higher snowfall reports received from each County.|Dryden (Lapeer) 16 inches.|Capac (St Clair) 16 inches.|Clarkston (Oakland) 15.5 inches.|Lexington (Sanilac) 12.3 inches.|Brighton (Livingston) 12.0 inches.|Ann Arbor (Washtenaw) 10.5 inches.|Grand Blanc (Genesee) 9.5 inches.|Cement City (Lenawee) 9.5 inches.|Armada (Macomb) 9.0 inches.|Plymouth (Wayne) 7.0 inches.|Marlette (Tuscola) 7.0 inches.|Owosso (Shiawassee) 6.2 inches.|Bridgeport (Saginaw) 5.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported 7 inches of snow in mostly a 6 hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Wisconsin into eastern Upper Michigan brought widespread heavy snow to much of the region on the 17th and 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten to twelve inches of snow was reported in the Germfask area in an 18-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface trough sinking south into the area produced widespread snowfall amounts of 2 to 6 inches, along and north of M59. A few locations received 6 inches within a 12 hour period. ||Here are some of the higher snowfall totals:|Merrill  (Saginaw)  6.0 inches.  |Linden   (Genesee)  6.0 inches.|Burton   (Genesee)  6.0 inches.|Oil City (Midland)  6.0 inches. |Lapeer   (Lapeer)   5.8 inches.

A strong low pressure system tracking west of the area allowed temperatures to reach into the upper 50s to middle 60s, record highs for the date. A few severe storms, producing both wind and hail damage, occurred mainly along and west of U.S. 23 during the mid evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five mobile homes sustained roof and shingle damage with numerous trees also reported blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through southeast Michigan just before midnight, with strong post frontal wind gusts of 50 to 60 mph reported across much of area. The highest winds occurred across the Thumb region, extending south into the Detroit Metro area. A few buildings and houses sustained damage, mostly shingle and roof damage. |Trees and power lines were blown down, which led to power outages. Utility companies reported thousands of residents and businesses lost power due to downed power lines across the northern Thumb region, with close to 100,000 in the Lower Peninsula, with a majority of those outages occurring in southeast Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local Newspaper reported an unoccupied mobile home was flipped over by strong winds along M-46 east of Decker Road in Marlette Township.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread dense fog was reported through much of this period.

A low pressure system tracked very close to Downtown Detroit during the early morning hours of New Years Day. Heavy snow fell to the west and north of this track and fell steadily at a rate of 1 to 2 inches per hour from roughly midnight to 0700 EST across much of the area. An intense snow band did set up between the M-59 and I-69 corridors, where snowfall rates actually approached 4 inches per hour at times. Consequently, a swath of 12 to 16 inches of snow fell roughly from Brighton in south Livingston County to Lexington in southeast St Clair County. North and south of this area, snowfall amounts quickly tapered off. This storm will be most remembered for the amount of snow that fell in such a short period of time. The bulk of the snowfall, including the amounts over one foot, fell in less than 7 hours. Here are some of the higher snowfall reports received from each County.|Dryden (Lapeer) 16 inches.|Capac (St Clair) 16 inches.|Clarkston (Oakland) 15.5 inches.|Lexington (Sanilac) 12.3 inches.|Brighton (Livingston) 12.0 inches.|Ann Arbor (Washtenaw) 10.5 inches.|Grand Blanc (Genesee) 9.5 inches.|Cement City (Lenawee) 9.5 inches.|Armada (Macomb) 9.0 inches.|Plymouth (Wayne) 7.0 inches.|Marlette (Tuscola) 7.0 inches.|Owosso (Shiawassee) 6.2 inches.|Bridgeport (Saginaw) 5.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported 16 inches of snow in mostly a 6 hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air in the wake of a strong cold front produced heavy lake effect snow showers on the 1st and 2nd across portions of west and north central Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in Rockland measured 15.4 inches of snow in 13 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air in the wake of a strong cold front produced heavy lake effect snow showers on the 1st and 2nd across portions of west and north central Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Herman reported 10.6 inches of snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system intensified rapidly as it passed north of Lake Superior.  Rain along the leading edge of the system changed to snow, as cold air blasted into the region on very strong winds during the night of the 29th.  Temperatures hovered near zero to the single digits above zero during the day on the 30th, with occasional blinding white-out conditions in falling and blowing snow.  Blizzard conditions occurred in the open country of Chippewa County, with near-blizzard conditions across much of the rest of Northern Michigan.  The highest snowfall amounts, 6 to 8 inches, occurred in an area from Waters to Petoskey in Northern Lower Michigan.  Wind gusts peaked from 40 to 50 mph.  Travel was heavily impacted in the region, and the Michigan State Police advised that no one venture out in much of North Central and Northwest Lower Michigan.  Parts of US-2 were closed west of St Ignace, and the Mackinac Bridge was closed to high profile vehicles.  There were numerous accidents on area roads.  School and event cancellations were widespread, and there were also sporadic power outages.

Very strong northwest winds in the wake of an Arctic cold front caused blizzard conditions and bitter cold wind chills over portions of Upper Michigan on the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread near-zero visibility in snow and blowing snow was reported across portions of northern Houghton County.  Northwest winds frequently gusting over 40 mph caused significant blowing and drifting of snow making some roads impassable. Wind chill readings also plummeted to 25 below to 35 below zero. Many area schools and businesses were closed on the 30th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system intensified rapidly as it passed north of Lake Superior.  Rain along the leading edge of the system changed to snow, as cold air blasted into the region on very strong winds during the night of the 29th.  Temperatures hovered near zero to the single digits above zero during the day on the 30th, with occasional blinding white-out conditions in falling and blowing snow.  Blizzard conditions occurred in the open country of Chippewa County, with near-blizzard conditions across much of the rest of Northern Michigan.  The highest snowfall amounts, 6 to 8 inches, occurred in an area from Waters to Petoskey in Northern Lower Michigan.  Wind gusts peaked from 40 to 50 mph.  Travel was heavily impacted in the region, and the Michigan State Police advised that no one venture out in much of North Central and Northwest Lower Michigan.  Parts of US-2 were closed west of St Ignace, and the Mackinac Bridge was closed to high profile vehicles.  There were numerous accidents on area roads.  School and event cancellations were widespread, and there were also sporadic power outages.

A cold front moved through Southeast Michigan. A secondary low then developed along the trailing front, with the center passing just south of the area. This allowed heavy precipitation to spread north into southeast Michigan, with predominantly snow along and north of M-59. Widespread heavy snowfall of 8 to 12 inches occurred along and north of I-69, with the heaviest snow, 16 to 18 inches occurring over Saginaw county, making this storm the biggest since the Blizzard of 1978. Strong northeast winds off of Saginaw Bay also lead to near blizzard conditions. Road Crews in Saginaw county could not keep up with the snow, which fell at a rate of 2-4 inches per hour. Two to three foot snow drifts left at least 50 cars stranded. Snowfall amounts tapered off south of I-69, as sleet mixed in, cutting down accumulations quickly, with less than 3 inches across Wayne County and points south.  |Here are some of the higher snowfall reports received from each county:|||Burt (Saginaw) 16.0 inches.|Birch Run (Saginaw) 16.0 inches.|Bridgeport (Saginaw) 15.0 inches.|Shields (Saginaw) 14.4 inches.|Bay City (Bay)   10.5 inches.|Burton (Genesee) 12.0 inches.|Montrose(Genesee) 12.0 inches.|Flint (Genesee) 11.2 inches.|Bad Axe (Huron) 11 inches.|Lapeer (Lapeer) 9.0 inches.|Howell (Livingston) 6.5 inches.|Armada (Macomb) 9.7 inches.|Shelby Twp (Macomb) 9.0 inches.|Midland (Midland) 10.0 inches.|Rochester (Oakland) 8. inches.|Ortonville (Oakland) 7.3 inches.|Marlette (Sanilac) 10.0 inches.|Deckerville (Sanilac) 9.0 inches.|Owosso (Shiawassee) 8.5 inches.|Corunna (Shiawassee) 8.0 inches.|Yale (St Clair)  12.0 inches.|Blaine (St Clair) 10.5 inches.|Fairgrove (Tuscola) 14.0 inches.|Caro (Tuscola) 11.5 inches.|Dexter (Washtenaw) 5.0 inches.

This snowfall occurred in a short 6 to 8 hour time frame, with the highest amounts occurring over Washtenaw and Lenawee counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front blasted portions of Upper Michigan with blizzard to near-blizzard conditions and occasional heavy snow on the 6th and 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Manistique AWOS reported wind gusts at or above 30 mph through much of the afternoon and evening of the 6th.  There was a public report of an estimated 12-14 inches of snow at Steuben for the 24 hours ending at 8 am on the 7th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front blasted portions of Upper Michigan with blizzard to near-blizzard conditions and occasional heavy snow on the 6th and 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter south of Wetmore reported 4.2 inches in the 12-hour period ending at 8 am on the 7th.  Winds also continued to gust near 30 mph into the early morning hours of the 7th causing blowing of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of temperatures falling into the teens below zero along with winds gusting near 30 mph at times caused wind chill readings to plummet to 35 below zero on the 30th.  Schools were closed throughout the county due to the bitter cold.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Houghton County Sheriff reported nine inches of snow in 12 hours between Chassell and Painesdale in the 12-hour period ending at 3 am on the 4th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed in the wake of a cold front and became heavy at times for the northwest wind snowbelts from the 3rd into the 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated eight inches of snow fell in 12 hours along and south of Highway M-38.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front blasted portions of Upper Michigan with blizzard to near-blizzard conditions and occasional heavy snow on the 6th and 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Ontonagon County Sheriff reported occasionally heavy snow in Ontonagon along with wind gusts to around 30 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front blasted portions of Upper Michigan with blizzard to near-blizzard conditions and occasional heavy snow on the 6th and 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts around 30 mph caused blowing and drifting of snow throughout much of the county.  The National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured 4.4 inches of snow in the 12-hour period ending at 7 pm. An observer west of Sundell, near the Alger-Marquette County line, estimated a foot of snow in the 24-hour period ending at 8 am on the 7th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong northwest winds in the wake of an Arctic cold front caused blizzard conditions and bitter cold wind chills over portions of Upper Michigan on the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread near-zero visibility in snow and blowing snow was reported across Keweenaw County.  Northwest winds frequently gusting over 40 mph caused significant blowing and drifting of snow making some roads impassable. Wind chill readings also plummeted to 25 below to 35 below zero. Many area schools and businesses were closed on the 30th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong northwest winds in the wake of an Arctic cold front caused blizzard conditions and bitter cold wind chills over portions of Upper Michigan on the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Localized blizzard to near-blizzard conditions in snow and blowing snow were reported in northern Schoolcraft County on the morning of the 30th. Northwest winds gusting over 35 mph at times caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow on area roads. Widespread snow amounts of four to seven inches were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong northwest winds in the wake of an Arctic cold front caused blizzard conditions and bitter cold wind chills over portions of Upper Michigan on the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of temperatures falling below zero along with winds gusting over 35 mph at times caused wind chill readings to plummet to 30 below zero on the 30th.  Schools were closed throughout the county on the 30th due to the bitter cold, including Northern Michigan University.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong northwest winds in the wake of an Arctic cold front caused blizzard conditions and bitter cold wind chills over portions of Upper Michigan on the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of temperatures falling into the teens below zero along with winds gusting over 25 mph at times caused wind chill readings to plummet to 35 below zero on the 30th.  Schools were closed throughout the county due to the bitter cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong northwest winds in the wake of an Arctic cold front caused blizzard conditions and bitter cold wind chills over portions of Upper Michigan on the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of temperatures falling into the teens below zero along with winds gusting near 30 mph at times caused wind chill readings to plummet to 35 below zero on the 30th.  Schools were closed throughout the county due to the bitter cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through Southeast Michigan. A secondary low then developed along the trailing front, with the center passing just south of the area. This allowed heavy precipitation to spread north into southeast Michigan, with predominantly snow along and north of M-59. Widespread heavy snowfall of 8 to 12 inches occurred along and north of I-69, with the heaviest snow, 16 to 18 inches occurring over Saginaw county, making this storm the biggest since the Blizzard of 1978. Strong northeast winds off of Saginaw Bay also lead to near blizzard conditions. Road Crews in Saginaw county could not keep up with the snow, which fell at a rate of 2-4 inches per hour. Two to three foot snow drifts left at least 50 cars stranded. Snowfall amounts tapered off south of I-69, as sleet mixed in, cutting down accumulations quickly, with less than 3 inches across Wayne County and points south.  |Here are some of the higher snowfall reports received from each county:|||Burt (Saginaw) 16.0 inches.|Birch Run (Saginaw) 16.0 inches.|Bridgeport (Saginaw) 15.0 inches.|Shields (Saginaw) 14.4 inches.|Bay City (Bay)   10.5 inches.|Burton (Genesee) 12.0 inches.|Montrose(Genesee) 12.0 inches.|Flint (Genesee) 11.2 inches.|Bad Axe (Huron) 11 inches.|Lapeer (Lapeer) 9.0 inches.|Howell (Livingston) 6.5 inches.|Armada (Macomb) 9.7 inches.|Shelby Twp (Macomb) 9.0 inches.|Midland (Midland) 10.0 inches.|Rochester (Oakland) 8. inches.|Ortonville (Oakland) 7.3 inches.|Marlette (Sanilac) 10.0 inches.|Deckerville (Sanilac) 9.0 inches.|Owosso (Shiawassee) 8.5 inches.|Corunna (Shiawassee) 8.0 inches.|Yale (St Clair)  12.0 inches.|Blaine (St Clair) 10.5 inches.|Fairgrove (Tuscola) 14.0 inches.|Caro (Tuscola) 11.5 inches.|Dexter (Washtenaw) 5.0 inches.
Very strong northwest winds in the wake of an Arctic cold front caused blizzard conditions and bitter cold wind chills over portions of Upper Michigan on the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Localized blizzard to near-blizzard conditions in snow and blowing snow were reported for areas along Lake Superior. Northwest winds gusting over 50 mph at times early morning on the 30th caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow on area roads. Wind chill readings also plummeted to 25 below to 35 below zero through the day. Many schools throughout Ontonagon County were closed on the 30th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong northwest winds in the wake of an Arctic cold front caused blizzard conditions and bitter cold wind chills over portions of Upper Michigan on the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Near-blizzard conditions in snow and blowing snow were reported for portions of Delta County on the morning of the 30th. Northwest winds gusting over 35 mph at times caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow on area roads. Wind chill readings also plummeted to 30 below  zero. Many schools throughout Delta County were closed on the 30th due to the harsh conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong northwest winds in the wake of an Arctic cold front caused blizzard conditions and bitter cold wind chills over portions of Upper Michigan on the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Near-blizzard conditions in snow and blowing snow were reported for portions of southern Schoolcraft County on the morning of the 30th. Northwest winds gusting over 40 mph at times caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow on area roads. Wind chill readings also plummeted to 25 below zero. Many area schools were closed on the 30th due to the harsh conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system intensified rapidly as it passed north of Lake Superior.  Rain along the leading edge of the system changed to snow, as cold air blasted into the region on very strong winds during the night of the 29th.  Temperatures hovered near zero to the single digits above zero during the day on the 30th, with occasional blinding white-out conditions in falling and blowing snow.  Blizzard conditions occurred in the open country of Chippewa County, with near-blizzard conditions across much of the rest of Northern Michigan.  The highest snowfall amounts, 6 to 8 inches, occurred in an area from Waters to Petoskey in Northern Lower Michigan.  Wind gusts peaked from 40 to 50 mph.  Travel was heavily impacted in the region, and the Michigan State Police advised that no one venture out in much of North Central and Northwest Lower Michigan.  Parts of US-2 were closed west of St Ignace, and the Mackinac Bridge was closed to high profile vehicles.  There were numerous accidents on area roads.  School and event cancellations were widespread, and there were also sporadic power outages.

The passage of an Arctic cold front on the 18th ushered in very cold air and bitter cold wind chill temperatures. Wind chill temperatures plummeted into the 20 below to 40 below zero range across much of the west and central interior of Upper Michigan from early on the 19th through the morning of the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observed wind chills were generally between 25 below to 40 below zero from early morning on the 19th to late morning on the 20th.

A strengthening low pressure system moved from the St Louis area toward Lake Huron.  Heavy snow occurred just left of the track of the low.  Accumulation rates of one to two inches per hour were common in the mid to late evening hours of the 10th, though these rates did not last long in any one place.  Accumulations were around six inches in a swath across Northwest and far Northern Lower Michigan.  The snow swath continued into Eastern Upper Michigan, with six to nine inches of snow along the I-75 corridor.  The highest snowfall amounts, from eight to nine inches, fell from Moran to Sault Ste Marie.

A Plains low pressure system spread moderate snow across portions of southern and eastern Upper Michigan on the 13th and 14th. Heavy lake effect snow also developed over Gogebic County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer near Carlshend measured seven inches of snow in a 24-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains low pressure system spread moderate snow across portions of southern and eastern Upper Michigan on the 13th and 14th. Heavy lake effect snow also developed over Gogebic County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Ironwood observer measured a storm total snowfall of 20.5 inches. Ten inches of snow was also reported in Bessemer during an 18-24 hour period. As a result of the heavy snowfall, Ironwood, Bessemer, Wakefield-Marenisco and Gogebic Community College all cancelled classes on the 14th.

A mature and strong winter storm tracked through the Eastern Ohio Valley on February 1st. A heavy burst of snow during the early morning hours lead to accumulations of 4 to 5.5 inches within a 6 hour period across parts of southeast Michigan, with 1 to 4 inches elsewhere. This lead to a difficult morning commute, as Saginaw County police agencies alone reported about 50 snow-related crashes. A dry slot moving into southeast Michigan during the mid to late morning hours, put an end to the heavy snow, with just some light accumulations occurring during the afternoon hours.

Widespread snow accumulations ranged from 2 to 5 inches with locally higher amounts, occurring in less than 9 hours.

A dry slot moving into southeast Michigan during the mid to late morning hours, put an end to the heavy snow, with just some light accumulations occurring during the afternoon hours.

A mature and strong winter storm tracked through the Eastern Ohio Valley on February 1st. A heavy burst of snow during the early morning hours lead to accumulations of 4 to 5.5 inches within a 6 hour period across parts of southeast Michigan, with 1 to 4 inches elsewhere. This lead to a difficult morning commute, as Saginaw County police agencies alone reported about 50 snow-related crashes. A dry slot moving into southeast Michigan during the mid to late morning hours, put an end to the heavy snow, with just some light accumulations occurring during the afternoon hours.

A dry slot moving into southeast Michigan during the mid to late morning hours, put an end to the heavy snow, with just some light accumulations occurring during the afternoon hours.

A strong upper level system crossing southern Lake Michigan allowed snow to spread into Southeast Michigan after 2 PM. |The snow intensified during the evening commute, causing very poor driving conditions. Widespread snow accumulations ranged from 2 to 5 inches with locally higher amounts, occurring in less than 9 hours.

A low pressure system tracked northeast, roughly along a line from Indianapolis to Detroit to London, Ontario. Four to seven inches of snow fell along and north of M-59, with an isolated total of 8.6 inches reported in Marlette. The snow begin during the late afternoon hours of November 30th and ended during the late morning of December 1st.

A low pressure system tracked through southeast Michigan, delivering 5 to 9 inches of snow north of I-69, with amounts quickly tapering off farther south as precipitation type was mostly rain. |Here are some of the higher snowfall totals reported:|Auburn (Bay) 8 inches.|Filion (Huron) 7.3 inches.|Hope (Midland) 9 inches.|Freeland (Saginaw) 7 inches.|Caro (Tuscola) 6.7 inches.

A strong upper level system crossing southern Lake Michigan allowed snow to spread into Southeast Michigan after 2 PM. |The snow intensified during the evening commute, causing very poor driving conditions. Widespread snow accumulations ranged from 2 to 5 inches with locally higher amounts, occurring in less than 9 hours.

A low pressure system tracked right along the Ohio River resulting in snow across southeast Michigan. Total snowfall amounts varied from south to north, with the highest amounts, up to 6 inches, occurring near the Ohio Border. Amounts tapered off to 2 to 4 inches along the M59 corridor, and only 1 to 2 inches across the I-69 corridor.

A cold front moved through Southeast Michigan. A secondary low then developed along the trailing front, with the center passing just south of the area. This allowed heavy precipitation to spread north into southeast Michigan, with predominantly snow along and north of M-59. Widespread heavy snowfall of 8 to 12 inches occurred along and north of I-69, with the heaviest snow, 16 to 18 inches occurring over Saginaw county, making this storm the biggest since the Blizzard of 1978. Strong northeast winds off of Saginaw Bay also lead to near blizzard conditions. Road Crews in Saginaw county could not keep up with the snow, which fell at a rate of 2-4 inches per hour. Two to three foot snow drifts left at least 50 cars stranded. Snowfall amounts tapered off south of I-69, as sleet mixed in, cutting down accumulations quickly, with less than 3 inches across Wayne County and points south.  |Here are some of the higher snowfall reports received from each county:|||Burt (Saginaw) 16.0 inches.|Birch Run (Saginaw) 16.0 inches.|Bridgeport (Saginaw) 15.0 inches.|Shields (Saginaw) 14.4 inches.|Bay City (Bay)   10.5 inches.|Burton (Genesee) 12.0 inches.|Montrose(Genesee) 12.0 inches.|Flint (Genesee) 11.2 inches.|Bad Axe (Huron) 11 inches.|Lapeer (Lapeer) 9.0 inches.|Howell (Livingston) 6.5 inches.|Armada (Macomb) 9.7 inches.|Shelby Twp (Macomb) 9.0 inches.|Midland (Midland) 10.0 inches.|Rochester (Oakland) 8. inches.|Ortonville (Oakland) 7.3 inches.|Marlette (Sanilac) 10.0 inches.|Deckerville (Sanilac) 9.0 inches.|Owosso (Shiawassee) 8.5 inches.|Corunna (Shiawassee) 8.0 inches.|Yale (St Clair)  12.0 inches.|Blaine (St Clair) 10.5 inches.|Fairgrove (Tuscola) 14.0 inches.|Caro (Tuscola) 11.5 inches.|Dexter (Washtenaw) 5.0 inches.

A strong low pressure system produced very windy conditions across southwestern lower Michigan on December the 28th.  The highest wind gusts occurred mainly before sunrise, however very gusty conditions persisted well into the afternoon.  Hundreds of thousands of people across the state lost power at least temporarily due to high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts up to 60 mph brought down several trees and power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system produced very windy conditions across southwestern lower Michigan on December the 28th.  The highest wind gusts occurred mainly before sunrise, however very gusty conditions persisted well into the afternoon.  Hundreds of thousands of people across the state lost power at least temporarily due to high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts up to 60 mph brought down several trees and power lines. A 54 mph gust was recorded at Reynolds field in Jackson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system produced very windy conditions across southwestern lower Michigan on December the 28th.  The highest wind gusts occurred mainly before sunrise, however very gusty conditions persisted well into the afternoon.  Hundreds of thousands of people across the state lost power at least temporarily due to high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 63 mph wind gust was recorded at the Lansing Capital City airport.  The high wind brought down several trees and power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system produced very windy conditions across southwestern lower Michigan on December the 28th.  The highest wind gusts occurred mainly before sunrise, however very gusty conditions persisted well into the afternoon.  Hundreds of thousands of people across the state lost power at least temporarily due to high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts up to 60 mph brought down several trees and power lines.  A measured wind gust to 55 mph was recorded at the Battle Creek airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light snow began late on the 20th, and evolved into a blizzard across portions of lower Michigan on the 21st. The blizzard conditions impacted the lakeshore counties from Oceana county south, where a total of six to as much as twelve inches of snow fell and was accompanied by wind gusts of 40 to 45 mph. ||This resulted in two to three foot snow drifts across portions of the area, which in conjunction with the blizzard to near blizzard conditions produced dangerous travel conditions. At the height of the storm, several stretches of highway were shut down due to multiple vehicle accidents.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to eight inches of snow fell and was accompanied by wind gusts up to 35 mph.

At the height of the storm, several stretches of highway were shut down due to multiple vehicle accidents.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to twelve inches of snow fell and was accompanied by wind gusts up to 45 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved from Kansas City, Missouri to north of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Snow spread into southwest lower Michigan out ahead of the low, starting in South Haven at around 2:00 a.m. on the nineteenth. ||The snow quickly spread north and began in Mount Pleasant at around 4:30 a.m.  Heavy Snow occurred across most of the area between 5:00 a.m. and 1:00 pm, with snowfall rates reaching 1 to 2 inches per hour at times.  Thundersnow was even reported at locations across southern lower Michigan, evidence to the instability in place with this system.  ||Some sleet and freezing rain mixed in along the Interstate 94 corridor. The heaviest snow occurred in a swath from Pentwater south to Holland, east through Newaygo, Grand Rapids, Alma and St. John's. Another maximum of snow was found across south central lower Michigan from Bellevue in Eaton county southeast to Vandercook Lake in Jackson county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A total of eight to twelve inches of snow was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow occurred on December 6th, with areas west of US-131 being the hardest hit.  The combination of snow and blowing snow behind the Alberta clipper system caused very hazardous travel conditions. The wind direction was from the south southwest during the morning, which resulted in heavy snow falling north and west of a line from Holland to Reed City. Over a foot of snow piled up across portions of Newaygo and Mason counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported eight to fourteen inches of snow and blowing snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to ten inches of snow and blowing snow was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through southeast Michigan just before midnight, with strong post frontal wind gusts of 50 to 60 mph reported across much of area. The highest winds occurred across the Thumb region, extending south into the Detroit Metro area. A few buildings and houses sustained damage, mostly shingle and roof damage. |Trees and power lines were blown down, which led to power outages. Utility companies reported thousands of residents and businesses lost power due to downed power lines across the northern Thumb region, with close to 100,000 in the Lower Peninsula, with a majority of those outages occurring in southeast Michigan.

A disorganized area of low pressure moved from western Kansas through lower Michigan.  Precipitation occurred over two periods.  The first was associated with strong warm advection well ahead of the surface low.  Most of the heavy snow fall occurred during this phase of the storm on December 23rd.  Another area of precipitation, mainly rain over the south half of the CWA hit the area on the 24th as the low center passed by. The precipitation ended as snow in most area north of I-96.||Total snow accumulations ranged from 6 to 12 inches in the west and north counties to as little as 1 to 3 inches in the far southeast part of the CWA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to ten inches of snow fell in Oceana county.  A period of sleet and rain was also reported before it changed back over to snow before ending.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A heavy snowfall of 4 to 8 inches occurred across the county.  The heaviest snow fell during the morning and early afternoon.  Light snow mixed briefly with sleet before changing to rain and drizzle as temperatures warmed above freezing early on December 24th.

The blizzard conditions impacted the lakeshore counties from Oceana county south, where a total of six to as much as twelve inches of snow fell and was accompanied by wind gusts of 40 to 45 mph. ||This resulted in two to three foot snow drifts across portions of the area, which in conjunction with the blizzard to near blizzard conditions produced dangerous travel conditions. At the height of the storm, several stretches of highway were shut down due to multiple vehicle accidents.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to ten inches of snow along with wind gusts to 45 mph was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light snow began late on the 20th, and evolved into a blizzard across portions of lower Michigan on the 21st. The blizzard conditions impacted the lakeshore counties from Oceana county south, where a total of six to as much as twelve inches of snow fell and was accompanied by wind gusts of 40 to 45 mph. ||This resulted in two to three foot snow drifts across portions of the area, which in conjunction with the blizzard to near blizzard conditions produced dangerous travel conditions. At the height of the storm, several stretches of highway were shut down due to multiple vehicle accidents.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to ten inches of snow along with wind gusts to 45 mph was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved from Kansas City, Missouri to north of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Snow spread into southwest lower Michigan out ahead of the low, starting in South Haven at around 2:00 a.m. on the nineteenth. ||The snow quickly spread north and began in Mount Pleasant at around 4:30 a.m.  Heavy Snow occurred across most of the area between 5:00 a.m. and 1:00 pm, with snowfall rates reaching 1 to 2 inches per hour at times.  Thundersnow was even reported at locations across southern lower Michigan, evidence to the instability in place with this system.  ||Some sleet and freezing rain mixed in along the Interstate 94 corridor. The heaviest snow occurred in a swath from Pentwater south to Holland, east through Newaygo, Grand Rapids, Alma and St. John's. Another maximum of snow was found across south central lower Michigan from Bellevue in Eaton county southeast to Vandercook Lake in Jackson county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A total of eight to twelve inches of snow was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system produced very windy conditions across southwestern lower Michigan on December the 28th.  The highest wind gusts occurred mainly before sunrise, however very gusty conditions persisted well into the afternoon.  Hundreds of thousands of people across the state lost power at least temporarily due to high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 61 mph wind gust was recorded at the Gerald Ford airport in Grand Rapids.  Numerous trees and power lines were blown down across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system produced very windy conditions across southwestern lower Michigan on December the 28th.  The highest wind gusts occurred mainly before sunrise, however very gusty conditions persisted well into the afternoon.  Hundreds of thousands of people across the state lost power at least temporarily due to high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 61 mph wind gust was measured at the Muskegon airport during the early morning hours of the 28th.  Several trees and power lines were blown down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to eight inches of snow and ice pellets were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to eight inches of snow fell and was accompanied by wind gusts up to 40 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A disorganized area of low pressure moved from western Kansas through lower Michigan.  Precipitation occurred over two periods.  The first was associated with strong warm advection well ahead of the surface low.  Most of the heavy snow fall occurred during this phase of the storm on December 23rd.  Another area of precipitation, mainly rain over the south half of the CWA hit the area on the 24th as the low center passed by. The precipitation ended as snow in most area north of I-96.||Total snow accumulations ranged from 6 to 12 inches in the west and north counties to as little as 1 to 3 inches in the far southeast part of the CWA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A heavy snowfall of 6 to 10 inches occurred across the county.  The heaviest snow fell during the morning and early afternoon.  Light snow changed to rain and drizzle as temperatures warmed above freezing early on December 24th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system produced very windy conditions across southwestern lower Michigan on December the 28th.  The highest wind gusts occurred mainly before sunrise, however very gusty conditions persisted well into the afternoon.  Hundreds of thousands of people across the state lost power at least temporarily due to high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 58 mph wind gust was recorded at the Kalamazoo airport.  Numerous trees and power lines were blown down across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of upper level disturbances combined with arctic air and resulted in a prolonged lake effect snow event for portions of western lower Michigan.  Greater than eight inches of snow fell in twenty four hours or less across portions of the lakeshore counties of western lower Michigan.||The heaviest lake effect snow occurred in a swath from northern Muskegon county north to southern Mason county, where approximately ten to fifteen inches of snow fell from 7 a.m. on the eighteenth to 7 a.m. on the twentieth.

A series of upper level disturbances combined with arctic air and resulted in a prolonged lake effect snow event for portions of western lower Michigan.  Greater than eight inches of snow fell in twenty four hours or less across portions of the lakeshore counties of western lower Michigan.||The heaviest lake effect snow occurred in a swath from northern Muskegon county north to southern Mason county, where approximately ten to fifteen inches of snow fell from 7 a.m. on the eighteenth to 7 a.m. on the twentieth.

A series of upper level disturbances combined with arctic air and resulted in a prolonged lake effect snow event for portions of western lower Michigan.  Greater than eight inches of snow fell in twenty four hours or less across portions of the lakeshore counties of western lower Michigan.||The heaviest lake effect snow occurred in a swath from northern Muskegon county north to southern Mason county, where approximately ten to fifteen inches of snow fell from 7 a.m. on the eighteenth to 7 a.m. on the twentieth.

The second big blast of snow, wind, and bitter cold in as many weeks.  In fact, this storm was extremely similar to the January 29-30 event.  Low pressure rapidly strengthened as it moved northeast away from Lake Superior.  Polar air surged into the region behind the departing system, dropping temperatures to around zero.  Lake effect and lake enhanced snow quickly developed, with a widespread two to five inches in the snowbelts.  There were isolated higher amounts of seven inches in Gaylord, nearly nine inches south of Traverse City, and eight inches near Trout Lake.  Wind gusts up to 45 mph, when combined with falling and blowing snow, produced outright blizzard conditions in the open country of central Chippewa County, and near blizzard conditions at times across much of the rest of Northern Michigan.  US-2 west of St Igance, the Mackinac Bridge, and part of I-75 in Sault Ste Marie, were all closed during the height of the event.  Traffic accidents also closed part of I-75 south of Gaylord.  In Leland, an 87-year-old male Alzheimers patient was found dead five blocks from his home on the morning of the 10th.  Local law enforcement stated he died of exposure to the cold.  A number of area schools were closed on the 11th (Monday) as the clean-up was still underway.

Cold north winds brought heavy lake effect snow to Leelanau County on the night of the 19th.  Most of the county saw seven to twelve inches of accumulation.  The highest amount, fourteen inches, fell a few miles east of Empire.  Localized six to eight inch amounts extended into far northern Benzie and Grand Traverse Counties, including the Old Mission Peninsula.

A powerful arctic cold front blasted through lower Michigan and produced severe winter conditions.  Temperatures at the Grand Rapids airport plummeted from 28 degrees at midnight on the ninth to 7 degrees at 6 am |on the tenth. Temperatures dropped to zero degrees by 11 am. ||Frequent wind gusts over 40 mph were common, especially near the Lake Michigan shoreline. This resulted in dangerous wind chills around twenty below zero.||Snowfall totals were greatest over Allegan and Van Buren counties. Snow drifts of three to five feet deep were common in rural and outlying areas. By the early morning hours of the tenth, snow bands became better developed and extended well inland. ||Whiteout conditions were occurring under these bands, with visibilities near zero in blowing and falling snow. A fifty car pileup occurred on I-196 in Ottawa county in the afternoon as a result of whiteout conditions.  Twenty people were treated for minor injuries, but there were no major injuries or fatalities.

A low pressure system moved into northern lower Michigan on the fourteenth, bringing a band of moderate to heavy snow into areas north of a line from Pentwater to Clare.  Total snow amounts of up to 12 inches were reported across portions of Mason and Lake counties.

Twenty people were treated for minor injuries, but there were no major injuries or fatalities.

The second big blast of snow, wind, and bitter cold in as many weeks.  In fact, this storm was extremely similar to the January 29-30 event.  Low pressure rapidly strengthened as it moved northeast away from Lake Superior.  Polar air surged into the region behind the departing system, dropping temperatures to around zero.  Lake effect and lake enhanced snow quickly developed, with a widespread two to five inches in the snowbelts.  There were isolated higher amounts of seven inches in Gaylord, nearly nine inches south of Traverse City, and eight inches near Trout Lake.  Wind gusts up to 45 mph, when combined with falling and blowing snow, produced outright blizzard conditions in the open country of central Chippewa County, and near blizzard conditions at times across much of the rest of Northern Michigan.  US-2 west of St Igance, the Mackinac Bridge, and part of I-75 in Sault Ste Marie, were all closed during the height of the event.  Traffic accidents also closed part of I-75 south of Gaylord.  In Leland, an 87-year-old male Alzheimers patient was found dead five blocks from his home on the morning of the 10th.  Local law enforcement stated he died of exposure to the cold.  A number of area schools were closed on the 11th (Monday) as the clean-up was still underway.

Low pressure moved across the Ohio Valley, and the north end of the heavier snowfall brushed Northern Lower Michigan.  Six to ten inches of snow fell from Wellston to Houghton Lake to Gladwin, with lesser amounts to the north.  Some blowing and drifting snow occurred, thanks to blustery east to northeast winds.

Southerly flow aloft brought relatively warm and moist air across the region.  A wintry mix of precipitation developed across Northern Michigan on the 17th.  Snow fell initially, but freezing rain became the most significant precipitation type.  Parts of Northern Lower Michigan picked up between a quarter and a third of an inch of ice accumulation.  A spotter in Posen (Presque Isle County) reported half an inch of ice accumulation.  Snow remained the dominant precipitation type in Eastern Upper Michigan, with five to eight inches of accumulation.

A low pressure system tracking through the Northern Great Lakes lead to a widespread snowfall around 2 inches across much of southeast Michigan with higher amounts from I-94 to the Ohio border of 3 to 5 inches. This snowfall occurred in a short 6 to 8 hour time frame, with the highest amounts occurring over Washtenaw and Lenawee counties.

A low pressure system moved into northern lower Michigan on the fourteenth, bringing a band of moderate to heavy snow into areas north of a line from Pentwater to Clare.  Total snow amounts of up to 12 inches were reported across portions of Mason and Lake counties.

A cold front moved through Southeast Michigan. A secondary low then developed along the trailing front, with the center passing just south of the area. This allowed heavy precipitation to spread north into southeast Michigan, with predominantly snow along and north of M-59. Widespread heavy snowfall of 8 to 12 inches occurred along and north of I-69, with the heaviest snow, 16 to 18 inches occurring over Saginaw county, making this storm the biggest since the Blizzard of 1978. Strong northeast winds off of Saginaw Bay also lead to near blizzard conditions. Road Crews in Saginaw county could not keep up with the snow, which fell at a rate of 2-4 inches per hour. Two to three foot snow drifts left at least 50 cars stranded. Snowfall amounts tapered off south of I-69, as sleet mixed in, cutting down accumulations quickly, with less than 3 inches across Wayne County and points south.  |Here are some of the higher snowfall reports received from each county:|||Burt (Saginaw) 16.0 inches.|Birch Run (Saginaw) 16.0 inches.|Bridgeport (Saginaw) 15.0 inches.|Shields (Saginaw) 14.4 inches.|Bay City (Bay)   10.5 inches.|Burton (Genesee) 12.0 inches.|Montrose(Genesee) 12.0 inches.|Flint (Genesee) 11.2 inches.|Bad Axe (Huron) 11 inches.|Lapeer (Lapeer) 9.0 inches.|Howell (Livingston) 6.5 inches.|Armada (Macomb) 9.7 inches.|Shelby Twp (Macomb) 9.0 inches.|Midland (Midland) 10.0 inches.|Rochester (Oakland) 8. inches.|Ortonville (Oakland) 7.3 inches.|Marlette (Sanilac) 10.0 inches.|Deckerville (Sanilac) 9.0 inches.|Owosso (Shiawassee) 8.5 inches.|Corunna (Shiawassee) 8.0 inches.|Yale (St Clair)  12.0 inches.|Blaine (St Clair) 10.5 inches.|Fairgrove (Tuscola) 14.0 inches.|Caro (Tuscola) 11.5 inches.|Dexter (Washtenaw) 5.0 inches.

A powerful arctic cold front blasted through lower Michigan and produced severe winter conditions.  Temperatures at the Grand Rapids airport plummeted from 28 degrees at midnight on the ninth to 7 degrees at 6 am |on the tenth. Temperatures dropped to zero degrees by 11 am. ||Frequent wind gusts over 40 mph were common, especially near the Lake Michigan shoreline. This resulted in dangerous wind chills around twenty below zero.||Snowfall totals were greatest over Allegan and Van Buren counties. Snow drifts of three to five feet deep were common in rural and outlying areas. By the early morning hours of the tenth, snow bands became better developed and extended well inland. ||Whiteout conditions were occurring under these bands, with visibilities near zero in blowing and falling snow. A fifty car pileup occurred on I-196 in Ottawa county in the afternoon as a result of whiteout conditions.  Twenty people were treated for minor injuries, but there were no major injuries or fatalities.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fifty car pileup occurred in the afternoon on I-196 in Ottawa county due to whiteout conditions in snow and blowing snow.  Twenty people were transferred to area hospitals with minor injuries, but there were no major injuries or fatalities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm developed in the Southern Plains and tracked into the area with a swath of mainly snow for far southern Lower Michigan. The precipitation did start as a period of sleet and even freezing rain. Most areas received 5 to 7 inches of snow along with blowing and drifting snow. Many schools were closed for the day, giving students a long weekend.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to seven inches of snow fell, as well as considerable blowing and drifting of the snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Easterly winds increased, well ahead of a strong low pressure system moving northeast from the Southern Plains.  Gusts to 40 mph downed tree limbs and power lines in the Cadillac area.  Around two thousand people lost power.  The same storm system also produced the last significant snowfall of the season.  Snow fell on the 11th into the morning of the 12th, with two to five inches from Gaylord northward, and isolated higher amounts in the Straits of Mackinac region.

Low pressure moved across central Indiana during during the evening hours of the 25th into much of the 26th with widespread snow across far southern Lower Michigan. In general 5 to 7 inches of snow fell across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to seven inches of snow fell across the county. The snow from the system quickly diminshed as a strong lake effect band set up across the far western parts of the county. This will be covered in a separate episode.

Six to ten inches of snow fell across far western lower Michigan.  The heaviest snow report came from Allegan county, where ten inches of snow was reported.
Six to ten inches of snow fell across far western lower Michigan.  The heaviest snow report came from Allegan county, where ten inches of snow was reported.

A rare mid winter severe weather event occurred and resulted in several reports of high winds and large hail.  There were few reports of damage associated with the severe weather.  However hail did briefly cover the ground near Mt. Pleasant, and one tree was blown down just southeast of Spring Arbor.  Two funnel clouds were also reported near Mt. Pleasant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven eighths inch diameter hail was reported by an amateur radio operator near Rustford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Six to ten inches of snow fell across far western lower Michigan.  The heaviest snow report came from Allegan county, where ten inches of snow was reported.
Six to ten inches of snow fell across far western lower Michigan.  The heaviest snow report came from Allegan county, where ten inches of snow was reported.

A vigorous low pressure system brought a round of moderate to heavy snow and strong winds to lower Michigan, resulting in blizzard to near blizzard conditions at times during the late evening and overnight hours.  The heaviest snowfall was reported mainly near and west of US-131 to the lakeshore, where around 4 to 7 inches of snow was reported. High winds accompanied the snow resulting in blizzard to near blizzard conditions overnight.||Storm impacts included very dangerous travel conditions during the late evening and overnight hours due to near zero visibility at times in snow and blowing snow.  Travel conditions remained treacherous during the morning hours of the 30th as a result of icy roads and blowing snow.  In fact over 500 schools were closed on the 30th due to icy roads and blowing snow.
Six to ten inches of snow fell across far western lower Michigan.  The heaviest snow report came from Allegan county, where ten inches of snow was reported.

Light snow began during the mid evening hours on New Years Eve of 2007. However, significant travel problems and accumulations did not begin until shortly after midnight of New Years Day. Heavy snow fell across much of far southern Lower Michigan during the first few days of 2008. Many locations seen on the order of 6 to 10 inches of snow across the area. However, a mesoscale band developed and allowed for a swath of locally higher accumulations across much of St Joseph, Branch and Hillsdale counties where accumulations from 10 to 14 inches was reported. In addition, lake enhanced snow bands developed, bring additional accumulatins to much of Berrien, Cass and western portions of St. Joseph counties. Isolated totals approached 2 feet by the end of the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of snow occurred across the county with widespread amounts ranging from 6 to 10 inches falling as the area of low pressure moved northeast into Michigan. Behind the system, several intense lake effect and lake enhanced bands of snow developed and allowed for significantly higher accumuations across much of Berrien county. By the time the snow ended, accumualtions of 16 to 20 inches were common with a narrow swath of 20 to 25 inches across far southern portions of the county near the Indiana and Michigan state line. Strong winds also caused widespread blowing and drifting of the snow.

Behind the system, several intense lake effect and lake enhanced bands of snow developed and allowed for significantly higher accumuations across much of Berrien county. By the time the snow ended, accumualtions as high as 16 inches was observed. Strong winds also caused widespread blowing and drifting of the snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of moderate to heavy snow occurred across the county with widespread amounts ranging from 6 to 9 inches. Strong winds also caused widespread blowing and drifting of the snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light snow began during the mid evening hours on New Years Eve of 2007. However, significant travel problems and accumulations did not begin until shortly after midnight of New Years Day. Heavy snow fell across much of far southern Lower Michigan during the first few days of 2008. Many locations seen on the order of 6 to 10 inches of snow across the area. However, a mesoscale band developed and allowed for a swath of locally higher accumulations across much of St Joseph, Branch and Hillsdale counties where accumulations from 10 to 14 inches was reported. In addition, lake enhanced snow bands developed, bring additional accumulatins to much of Berrien, Cass and western portions of St. Joseph counties. Isolated totals approached 2 feet by the end of the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of moderate to heavy snow occurred across the county with widespread amounts ranging from 8 to 12 inches with isolated reports of up to 14 inches in the far northeastern part of Hillsdale county. Strong winds also caused widespread blowing and drifting of the snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved across the Ohio Valley, and the north end of the heavier snowfall brushed Northern Lower Michigan.  Six to ten inches of snow fell from Wellston to Houghton Lake to Gladwin, with lesser amounts to the north.  Some blowing and drifting snow occurred, thanks to blustery east to northeast winds.

Low pressure moved across the Ohio Valley, and the north end of the heavier snowfall brushed Northern Lower Michigan. A widespread snowstorm produced near blizzard conditions across much of central and southern lower Michigan in the afternoon and evening of February sixth.  Snowfall rates of one to two inches per hour occurred in the heaviest snow bands.||The height of the storm happened during the afternoon and evening commute, producing near zero visibilities and snow covered roads, making for very treacherous travel conditions. By the time the snow tapered off at around midnight, snow totals in excess of a foot were reported north of Interstate 96 to Route 10. ||Further south along the Interstate 94 corridor, a wintry mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain occurred, limiting snowfall totals. The storm developed down in Texas and strengthened as it tracked into Indiana.

A low pressure system tracked northeast between Toledo and Cleveland and brought significant snowfall to most of southern lower Michigan on the first of February.  ||The heaviest snow occurred between midnight and daybreak before gradually diminishing during the mid to late morning hours. Snow continued to taper off to flurries in the afternoon before ending.  ||Approximately five to seven inches of snow fell south of a line from Muskegon to Clare.  There were several reports of eight inches of snow south and southwest of Grand Rapids, from Grand Haven to Burnips and Battle Creek.

A powerful Arctic cold front pushed through the Upper Great Lakes on the afternoon and evening of the 9th and produced blizzard conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow over portions of Upper Michigan into the 10th. Bitterly cold wind chills of 30 below to 40 below zero were observed over much of Upper Michigan from the night of the 9th into the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusting over 40 mph at times caused widespread whiteout conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow, especially along the Lake Superior shoreline. Visibility reported by the Luce County Airport AWOS was one-quarter mile or less through much of the period as wind chills lowered to 20 below zero on the 10th. ||The observer in Two Heart reported a snowfall total of 12 to 14 inches in the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 10th. Many area roads and highways were closed due to the blizzard conditions.

Bitterly cold wind chills of 30 below to 40 below zero were observed over much of Upper Michigan from the night of the 9th into the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow and blowing snow reduced visibility less than one quarter mile over much of the county.  Extreme blowing and drifting of snow from 40 to 50 mph wind gusts forced the closure of Highway 28 from far eastern Marquette County to Munising on the morning of the 10th as wind chills dropped to 20 below to 30 below zero.  Munising Area Schools were closed on the 11th as roads were still being cleared. Four to six inches of snow were observed during the blizzard event.

Low pressure tracking from Missouri into Lower Michigan spread wet heavy snow across central and eastern Upper Michigan on the afternoon and evening of the 17th. Lake effect snow showers developing behind the storm added a few more inches to snow totals over the north central Lake Superior snowbelts into the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Menominee to Stephenson reported six to nine inches of snow in the 12-hour period ending early evening on the 17th. Law enforcement officials reported numerous accidents due to snowpacked and slippery roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous low pressure system brought a round of moderate to heavy snow and strong winds to lower Michigan, resulting in blizzard to near blizzard conditions at times during the late evening and overnight hours.  The heaviest snowfall was reported mainly near and west of US-131 to the lakeshore, where around 4 to 7 inches of snow was reported. High winds accompanied the snow resulting in blizzard to near blizzard conditions overnight.||Storm impacts included very dangerous travel conditions during the late evening and overnight hours due to near zero visibility at times in snow and blowing snow.  Travel conditions remained treacherous during the morning hours of the 30th as a result of icy roads and blowing snow.  In fact over 500 schools were closed on the 30th due to icy roads and blowing snow.

A powerful Arctic cold front pushed through the Upper Great Lakes on the afternoon and evening of the 9th and produced blizzard conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow over portions of Upper Michigan into the 10th. Bitterly cold wind chills of 30 below to 40 below zero were observed over much of Upper Michigan from the night of the 9th into the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures of 5 to 10 below zero combined with wind gusts over 35 mph at times to produce wind chills between 25 below and 38 below zero across the county on the 10th. Although winds subsided by the evening of the 10th...actual temperatures fell to 10 to 15 below zero during the early morning of the 11th with wind chills near 30 below zero.  Many schools were either canceled or delayed on the 11th. AAA Michigan reportedly responded to numerous motorists' calls of dead batteries or fuel line freezes during the extreme cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful Arctic cold front pushed through the Upper Great Lakes on the afternoon and evening of the 9th and produced blizzard conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow over portions of Upper Michigan into the 10th. Bitterly cold wind chills of 30 below to 40 below zero were observed over much of Upper Michigan from the night of the 9th into the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures around 10 below zero combined with wind gusts over 35 mph to produce wind chills between 30 below and 40 below zero across the county on the 10th. The Amasa observer reported four inches and lowered visibility during the passage of the cold front on the 10th. ||Although winds subsided by the evening of the 10th...actual temperatures fell to near 20 below zero during the early morning of the 11th with wind chills near 30 below zero.  School classes were delayed two hours in West Iron County on the 11th. AAA Michigan reportedly responded to numerous motorists' calls of dead batteries or fuel line freezes during the extreme cold.

Low pressure tracked across portions of northern Indiana, spreading a swath of moderate to heavy snow across parts of far southern Lower Michigan. Accumulations of 6 to locally as much as a foot of snow occurred with the highest observed in Coldwater in Branch County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported six to eight inches of snow falling across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front worked across the area during the afternoon and evening hours of the 11th. Strong wind fields were in place along with modest instability to support narrow lines of thunderstorms. A few of these storms became strong and locally severe across far southern Lower Michigan. Spotters reported pea size hail with many of the storms, with one storm moving through the Coldwater area producing penny size hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operators observed penny size hail at the Coldwater airport.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures of 5 below to 10 below zero combined with wind gusts over 30 mph to produce wind chills between 25 below and 34 below zero at the Sawyer International Airport observing station.

An isolated marginally severe storm popped up over Saint Clair county, producing nickel size hail and wind gusts to 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported tree limbs down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated marginally severe storm popped up over Saint Clair county, producing nickel size hail and wind gusts to 60 mph.

A line of thunderstorms swept across Northern Lower Michigan on the night of the 25th.  Damaging wind gusts occurred in spots within the line, and there were a couple of reports with penny sized hail.  Several strong thunderstorms popped up ahead of the line, but just one of those produced severe weather, with large hail near Saginaw Bay late in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were downed onto power lines in western Mancelona Township, including near Cedar River Rd and Doerr Rd.

The Four Mile Road Fire developed early in the afternoon on the 24th, a few miles south-southeast of Grayling.  Sparks from a passing train were a possible cause.  It was a warm, dry, windy day, and a Red Flag Warning was in effect.  The fire quickly expanded as it raced to the northwest, crossing I-75 by late afternoon between the Four Mile Road and I-75 Business Loop exits.  Eventually, 1300 acres were burned, and the fire threatened the Ramada Inn and Admiral gas station on the far south end of Grayling.  However, the only structures lost were about half a dozen cabins near the Simpson Lakes, about two miles south of downtown Grayling.  Damage at the Grayling Game Club was near $287,000.  In addition, a State of Michigan Department of Natural Resources (DNR) transport truck, used to bring bulldozers to the fire line, was claimed by the fire.  Total cost of the fire to the DNR was $619,000.  This included both the cost of suppressing the fire, and damage done to timber and the transport.  (Note that fire suppression costs are not considered damages done by the fire.)  Power was lost in Grayling, fifty homes were evacuated, and I-75 was closed for several hours.  The fire slowed considerably that evening as winds and temperatures decreased.  Several periods of rain, beginning that night and continuing into the night of the 25th, helped extinguish the blaze.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large trees were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms swept across Northern Lower Michigan on the night of the 25th.  Damaging wind gusts occurred in spots within the line, and there were a couple of reports with penny sized hail.  Several strong thunderstorms popped up ahead of the line, but just one of those produced severe weather, with large hail near Saginaw Bay late in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few large trees were downed along M-55, seven miles west of Wellston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Brief heavy snow spread into south central and eastern Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 4th ahead of low pressure system approaching from the Plains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer near Two Heart measured 5.5 inches in less than eight hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Brief heavy snow spread into south central and eastern Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 4th ahead of low pressure system approaching from the Plains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Stephenson measured five inches of snow on the afternoon of the 4th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Brief heavy snow spread into south central and eastern Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 4th ahead of low pressure system approaching from the Plains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals on the afternoon of the 4th included four inches at Grand Marais and five inches south of Wetmore.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Brief heavy snow spread into south central and eastern Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 4th ahead of low pressure system approaching from the Plains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported four to five inches of snow in northeast Delta County on the afternoon of the 4th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful Arctic cold front pushed through the Upper Great Lakes on the afternoon and evening of the 9th and produced blizzard conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow over portions of Upper Michigan into the 10th. Bitterly cold wind chills of 30 below to 40 below zero were observed over much of Upper Michigan from the night of the 9th into the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rockland observer reported whiteout conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow as winds in Ontonagon gusted over 50 mph at times during the blizzard event. Wind chills also lowered to 30 below to 40 below zero on the 10th. Area roads and highways were closed due the blizzard conditions as snow amounts totaled four to six inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful Arctic cold front pushed through the Upper Great Lakes on the afternoon and evening of the 9th and produced blizzard conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow over portions of Upper Michigan into the 10th. Bitterly cold wind chills of 30 below to 40 below zero were observed over much of Upper Michigan from the night of the 9th into the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Houghton County Airport reported visibility less than one quarter mile in lake effect snow and blowing snow through much of the blizzard event as winds gusted over 50 miles at times.  Wind chills also lowered to 30 below to 40 below zero on the 10th.  Road closures from the blizzard continued into the 11th and caused two-hour delays in school start times. Four to six inches of snow were observed during the blizzard event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful Arctic cold front pushed through the Upper Great Lakes on the afternoon and evening of the 9th and produced blizzard conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow over portions of Upper Michigan into the 10th. Bitterly cold wind chills of 30 below to 40 below zero were observed over much of Upper Michigan from the night of the 9th into the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Mohawk reported visibility less than 500 feet in lake effect snow and blowing snow through much of the period.  The Houghton County Airport, ten miles to the southwest, reported frequent wind gusts greater than 40 mph with even a few gusts over 50 mph as wind chills lowered to 30 below to 40 below zero on the 10th. Highway 41 was closed from Delaware to Copper Harbor until early on the 11th due to the blizzard conditions which resulted in two-hour delays for area schools. Four to six inches of snow were reported during the blizzard event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A widespread snowstorm produced near blizzard conditions across much of central and southern lower Michigan in the afternoon and evening of February sixth.  Snowfall rates of one to two inches per hour occurred in the heaviest snow bands.||The height of the storm happened during the afternoon and evening commute, producing near zero visibilities and snow covered roads, making for very treacherous travel conditions. By the time the snow tapered off at around midnight, snow totals in excess of a foot were reported north of Interstate 96 to Route 10. ||Further south along the Interstate 94 corridor, a wintry mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain occurred, limiting snowfall totals. The storm developed down in Texas and strengthened as it tracked into Indiana.

The Detroit Metro Area took the brunt of this snow storm, as low pressure tracked northeast out of Tennessee to near Pittsburgh Pennsylvania. An initially very dry air mass in place over southeast Michigan lead to a sharp northwest to southeast cutoff in snow amounts. The majority of snow fell in a 9 hour period with mostly 4-7 inches reported south of M-59. Downriver Detroit did see as much as 10 inches however.
