A line of thunderstorms swept across Northern Lower Michigan on the night of the 25th.  Damaging wind gusts occurred in spots within the line, and there were a couple of reports with penny sized hail.  Several strong thunderstorms popped up ahead of the line, but just one of those produced severe weather, with large hail near Saginaw Bay late in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mostly pea sized hail, but a few hailstones as large as nickels.

An initially very dry air mass in place over southeast Michigan lead to a sharp northwest to southeast cutoff in snow amounts. The majority of snow fell in a 9 hour period with mostly 4-7 inches reported south of M-59. Downriver Detroit did see as much as 10 inches however.

A strong low pressure system tracking west of the area allowed temperatures to reach into the upper 50s to middle 60s, record highs for the date. A few severe storms, producing both wind and hail damage, occurred mainly along and west of U.S. 23 during the mid evening hours.

A low pressure system brought heavy snow to much of southwestern lower Michigan from the 21st through the 22nd.  Snow began during the morning hours of the 21st and continued into the early morning hours of the 22nd before gradually diminishing.  ||The heaviest snow fell during the afternoon and early evening hours of the 21st, when snowfall rates of two inches per hour were reported at some locations.  The highest snowfall totals were received from Allegan, Van Buren and Kalamazoo counties, where over a foot of snow was reported at some locations.  Eight to fourteen inches of snow fell south of a line from Holland to Jackson.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The seven inches of snow measured at the Muskegon airport was a record for the 21st of March, breaking the old record of 6.5 inches which was set in 1983.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system tracked through the Ohio Valley, resulting in heavy snow along and south of M-59. There was a very sharp cutoff to the snow to the north, as little accumulating snow occured north of I-69. ||Here are the average snowfall ranges reported across each county:|Lenawee 7-10 inches.|Livingston 3-6 inches.|Macomb 2-5 inches. |Monroe 6-10 inches. |Oakland 2-6 inches. |Washtenaw 7-10 inches. |Wayne 5-7 inches.

Very strong northwest winds in the wake of an Arctic cold front caused blizzard conditions and bitter cold wind chills over portions of Upper Michigan on the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread near-zero visibility in snow and blowing snow was reported across much of Alger County.  Northwest winds frequently gusting over 40 mph caused significant drifting of snow and whiteout conditions on Michigan Highways 28 and 94 on the morning of the 30th.  Many area schools were closed on the 30th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong northwest winds in the wake of an Arctic cold front caused blizzard conditions and bitter cold wind chills over portions of Upper Michigan on the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread near-zero visibility in snow and blowing snow was reported across much of Northern Luce County.  Northwest winds frequently gusting over 35 mph caused significant drifting of snow and whiteout conditions. Many area schools were closed on the 30th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Detroit Metro Area took the brunt of this snow storm, as low pressure tracked northeast out of Tennessee to near Pittsburgh Pennsylvania. An initially very dry air mass in place over southeast Michigan lead to a sharp northwest to southeast cutoff in snow amounts. The majority of snow fell in a 9 hour period with mostly 4-7 inches reported south of M-59. Downriver Detroit did see as much as 10 inches however.

Strong low pressure tracked from Arkansas into central Ohio, bringing a swath of precipitation to all of far southern Lower Michigan. Much of the area only saw a trace of snow to 3 inches...west of Interstate 69, as drier air and less moisture were in place across the area. To the east, across much of Hillsdale County, a narrow band of five to eight inches of snow blanketed the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported six to eight inches of snow across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The passage of an Arctic front on the 18th brought significant lake effect snow accumulation to the northwest wind snowbelts downwind of Lake Superior from the 18th into the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Grand Marais measured ten inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The passage of an Arctic front on the 18th brought significant lake effect snow accumulation to the northwest wind snowbelts downwind of Lake Superior from the 18th into the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer in northern Luce County reported 12 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow showers dumped at least a foot of snow accumulation in several hours over portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula on the afternoon of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Ahmeek estimated twelve inches of snow accumulation in four hours on the afternoon of the 21st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow showers dumped at least a foot of snow accumulation in several hours over portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula on the afternoon of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Laurium estimated twelve inches of snow accumulation in four hours on the afternoon of the 21st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deepening low pressure moved into northwestern Wisconsin with a strong cold front extending from it into the southern Great Lakes. Abundant moisture and a strong wind field set the state for a line of strong to severe storms to move into extreme southern Lower Michigan during the late evening hours of April 25th into the early morning hours of the 26th. While most activity remained below severe limits, a small cluster of storms was able to tap the strong wind fields and cause damaging winds in some areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local newspaper reported that a tree fell onto a car. No specifics on the car or the amount of damage was given. Damage is estimated at $10,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deepening low pressure moved into northwestern Wisconsin with a strong cold front extending from it into the southern Great Lakes. Abundant moisture and a strong wind field set the state for a line of strong to severe storms to move into extreme southern Lower Michigan during the late evening hours of April 25th into the early morning hours of the 26th. While most activity remained below severe limits, a small cluster of storms was able to tap the strong wind fields and cause damaging winds in some areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local law enforcement reported trees and power lines blown down by estimated winds of around 65 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deepening low pressure moved into northwestern Wisconsin with a strong cold front extending from it into the southern Great Lakes. Abundant moisture and a strong wind field set the state for a line of strong to severe storms to move into extreme southern Lower Michigan during the late evening hours of April 25th into the early morning hours of the 26th. While most activity remained below severe limits, a small cluster of storms was able to tap the strong wind fields and cause damaging winds in some areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local law enforcement reproted a tree was blown down on a road in Three Rivers.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system originating over the Plains deepened as it moved into the Western Great Lakes on the 31st. Snow mixed with rain and sleet over east and south central counties of Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 31st and then fell heavy at times through the evening of the 31st and the morning of April 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate snow began on the evening of the 31st and continued into the morning of April 1st. Storm total snowfall amounts of four to six inches were reported across northern Houghton County ending on the morning of the 1st. North winds gusting over 30 mph at times also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system originating over the Plains deepened as it moved into the Western Great Lakes on the 31st. Snow mixed with rain and sleet over east and south central counties of Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 31st and then fell heavy at times through the evening of the 31st and the morning of April 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow began on the evening of the 31st and continued into the morning of April 1st. Storm total snowfall amounts of six to nine inches were reported across Keweenaw County ending on the morning of the 1st. North winds gusting over 30 mph at times also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service storm survey determined that damage in the  southeast corner of Allegan county northeast into Barry county was caused by an EF-1 tornado. The tornado was on the ground for nearly five miles and did significant damage to a horse barn, lifted a trailer adjacent to the barn, damaged gravel yard equipment, lofted a tank, and uprooted numerous large trees.  Some trees were snapped off.  There were no injuries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service storm survey determined that the EF-1 tornado that touched down just southwest of 388 3rd Street in the southeast corner of Allegan county continued northeast into Barry county. The tornado knocked down numerous trees near Pine Lake, southwest of Prairieville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service storm survey determined that damage in the  southeast corner of Allegan county northeast into Barry county was caused by an EF-1 tornado. The tornado was on the ground for nearly five miles and did significant damage to a horse barn, lifted a trailer adjacent to the barn, damaged gravel yard equipment, lofted a tank, and uprooted numerous large trees.  Some trees were snapped off.  There were no injuries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service storm survey determined that damage in the vicinity of 388 3rd Street in the southeast corner of Allegan county was caused by a tornado. The tornado was rated an EF-1 on the Enhanced Fujita Damage Scale. The tornado touched down just southwest of the above address in Allegan county.||The tornado was on the ground for nearly five miles, and traveled to the northeast. It did significant damage to a horse barn, lifted a trailer adjacent to the barn, damaged gravel yard equipment, lofted a tank, and uprooted numerous large trees. Some trees were snapped off.||No one was injured. The damage was concentrated about four miles east of Plainwell and extended from the 300 block of 102nd Avenue to the northeast, crossing 106th Avenue in the 100 to 200 block section.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm dropped large hail over Schoolcraft County on the 17th.
A clipper low pressure system tracking across the area spread moderate snow over northern Houghton County on the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in Houghton and Painesdale measured four inches of snow over a 12-hour period.

An Alberta clipper low pressure system tracked across Lake Superior and spread snow and lake effect snow across northwest and northeast portions of Upper Michigan on February 29 continuing into March 1.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eleven inches of snow was reported at Melstrand in a 24-hour period ending on the morning of March 1. The Shingleton observer measured 7.5 inches of snowfall during the same period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta clipper low pressure system tracked across Lake Superior and spread snow and lake effect snow across northwest and northeast portions of Upper Michigan on February 29 continuing into March 1.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to seven inches of snow was reported over Luce County during a 24-hour period ending on March 1.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta clipper low pressure system tracked across Lake Superior and spread snow and lake effect snow across northwest and northeast portions of Upper Michigan on February 29 continuing into March 1.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer in Houghton measured 5.5 inches of snow in the 24-hour period ending on the morning of March 1.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of high wind gusts in association with a round of severe thunderstorms that resulted in wind damage on May 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One large tree was blown down just south of St. John's.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of high wind gusts in association with a round of severe thunderstorms that resulted in wind damage on May 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported that a healthy tree two feet in diameter was blown down near St. John's.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm resulted in several reports of wind damage across Ottawa county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were blown down about a mile east of Port Sheldon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm resulted in several reports of wind damage across Ottawa county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported a tree blown down just southeast of Grand Haven.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm resulted in several reports of wind damage across Ottawa county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement in Allendale reported that one tree was blown down across a road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts in association with an isolated severe thunderstorm blew down a couple of trees in Van Buren county on May 2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One tree was blown down in Lawrence township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of high wind gusts in association with a round of severe thunderstorms that resulted in wind damage on May 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An emergency manager reported that several trees were blown down at Big Star Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of high wind gusts in association with a round of severe thunderstorms that resulted in wind damage on May 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were blown down by thunderstorm wind gusts in White Cloud.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of high wind gusts in association with a round of severe thunderstorms that resulted in wind damage on May 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement in Rosebush reported that several power poles were snapped.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of high wind gusts in association with a round of severe thunderstorms that resulted in wind damage on May 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were blown down in Howard City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of high wind gusts in association with a round of severe thunderstorms that resulted in wind damage on May 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement officers a half a mile west of McBride repored that several trees were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of high wind gusts in association with a round of severe thunderstorms that resulted in wind damage on May 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media reported that a power line was blown down just north northwest of Sheperd at the intersection of US-27 and Walton road, which temporarily closed US-27 at that location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of high wind gusts in association with a round of severe thunderstorms that resulted in wind damage on May 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were blown down in Hubbardston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of high wind gusts in association with a round of severe thunderstorms that resulted in wind damage on May 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement in Portland reported that several trees were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts in association with an isolated severe thunderstorm blew down a couple of trees in Van Buren county on May 2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One tree was blown down in Hartford township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another low pressure system developing in the Plains tracked northeast toward the Upper Midwest and dropped heavy snow over portions of south central Upper Michigan on the evening of the 9th continuing into the morning of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inches of snow fell in Iron River over a 12-hour period. Poor driving  conditions during the storm were responsible for a three-to-four car collision south of Crystal Falls on Highway US-2 in Mastodon Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another low pressure system developing in the Plains tracked northeast toward the Upper Midwest and dropped heavy snow over portions of south central Upper Michigan on the evening of the 9th continuing into the morning of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inches of snow fell in a 12-hour period at Rock.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm developed over the Plains and tracked northeast into the Upper Great Lakes. The storm dropped widespread heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the evening of the 10th into the afternoon of the 12th. Blizzard conditions also occurred over the Keweenaw Peninsula on the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mohawk observer reported blizzard conditions throughout much of the morning of the 11th. An observer near Eagle River reported a storm total snowfall of 18 inches ending on the morning of the 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A round of severe thunderstorms resulted in numerous reports of large hail during the afternoon hours of April the eleventh.  Hail briefly covered the ground at several locations and there were several reports of broken windshields from hail in Parma in Jackson county.

A low pressure system originating over the Plains deepened as it moved into the Western Great Lakes on March 31st. Snow mixed with rain and sleet over east and south central counties of Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 31st and then fell heavy at times through the evening of March 31st into April 1st. ||The combination of heavy snow and north winds gusting as high as 50 mph near the Lake Superior shore lead to blizzard conditions as well as numerous power outages over Marquette and Alger counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The town of Rock received an estimated total of 18 inches of snow in the   |24-hour period ending early afternoon on the 1st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system originating over the Plains deepened as it moved into the Western Great Lakes on March 31st. Snow mixed with rain and sleet over east and south central counties of Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 31st and then fell heavy at times through the evening of March 31st into April 1st. ||The combination of heavy snow and north winds gusting as high as 50 mph near the Lake Superior shore lead to blizzard conditions as well as numerous power outages over Marquette and Alger counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer 11 miles north of Manistique measured ten inches of snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A round of severe thunderstorms resulted in numerous reports of large hail during the afternoon hours of April the eleventh.  Hail briefly covered the ground at several locations and there were several reports of broken windshields from hail in Parma in Jackson county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report that large hail up to one and three quarters inches in diameter dented a car, but did not break the windshield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system originating over the Plains deepened as it moved into the Western Great Lakes on March 31st. Snow mixed with rain and sleet over east and south central counties of Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 31st and then fell heavy at times through the evening of March 31st into April 1st. ||The combination of heavy snow and north winds gusting as high as 50 mph near the Lake Superior shore lead to blizzard conditions as well as numerous power outages over Marquette and Alger counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Munising ASOS reported frequent north wind gusts over 35 mph from 2 am to 2 pm on the 1st.  For several hours in the early morning, wind gusts were measured at 45 mph or higher.  During the time of the strong winds,  storm total snowfall amounts of 10 to 12 inches were being reported from Eben Junction to Chatham and Munising resulting in widespread blizzard conditions across the area. Deputies in Alger County reported numerous minor accidents due to the blizzard conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another low pressure system developing in the Plains tracked northeast toward the Upper Midwest and dropped heavy snow over portions of south central Upper Michigan on the evening of the 9th continuing into the morning of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in Hardwood and Norway measured seven inches of heavy snow in 12 hours while eight inches accumulated in Iron Mountain.  The snow forced the cancellation of schools in the Norway and Iron Mountain districts as well as North Dickinson and Pine Mountain Christian in Breitung Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm developed over the Plains and tracked northeast into the Upper Great Lakes. The storm dropped widespread heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the evening of the 10th into the afternoon of the 12th. Blizzard conditions also occurred over the Keweenaw Peninsula on the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer ten miles south of Grand Marais measured eight inches in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm developed over the Plains and tracked northeast into the Upper Great Lakes. The storm dropped widespread heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the evening of the 10th into the afternoon of the 12th. Blizzard conditions also occurred over the Keweenaw Peninsula on the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated eight inches of snow fell in 12 hours near the Schoolcraft/Alger County line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm developed over the Plains and tracked northeast into the Upper Great Lakes. The storm dropped widespread heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the evening of the 10th into the afternoon of the 12th. Blizzard conditions also occurred over the Keweenaw Peninsula on the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer in Bark River near the Delta/Menominee County line measured nine inches of snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system originating over the Plains deepened as it moved into the Western Great Lakes on March 31st. Snow mixed with rain and sleet over east and south central counties of Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 31st and then fell heavy at times through the evening of March 31st into April 1st. ||The combination of heavy snow and north winds gusting as high as 50 mph near the Lake Superior shore lead to blizzard conditions as well as numerous power outages over Marquette and Alger counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: COOP observers reported 24-hour snowfall totals of twelve inches near Stambaugh and eight to nine inches at Iron River and Amasa.  North winds gusting over 30 mph at times causing considerable blowing and drifting of the heavy snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm developed over the Plains and tracked northeast into the Upper Great Lakes. The storm dropped widespread heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the evening of the 10th into the afternoon of the 12th. Blizzard conditions also occurred over the Keweenaw Peninsula on the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer in Bark River near the Delta/Menominee County line measured nine inches of snow in 24 hours.  Gladstone in Delta County recorded a total of 2.25 inches of water equivalent precipitation during the event from early on the 11th through the morning of the 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few thunderstorms dropped large hail over western Upper Michigan on the evening of the 25th ahead of strong cold front moving through the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail covered the ground in Chassell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few thunderstorms dropped large hail over western Upper Michigan on the evening of the 25th ahead of strong cold front moving through the area.
A few thunderstorms dropped large hail over western Upper Michigan on the evening of the 25th ahead of strong cold front moving through the area.
A cold front moved through the area during the early evening hours, triggering widespread marginal severe thunderstorms along and north of the M-59 corridor.

The storm dropped widespread heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the evening of the 10th into the afternoon of the 12th. Blizzard conditions also occurred over the Keweenaw Peninsula on the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to five inches of snow fell in 12 hours at Germfask.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system originating over the Plains deepened as it moved into the Western Great Lakes on March 31st. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm developed over the Plains and tracked northeast into the Upper Great Lakes. The storm dropped widespread heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the evening of the 10th into the afternoon of the 12th. Blizzard conditions also occurred over the Keweenaw Peninsula on the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at the Houghton County Airport reported blizzard conditions from 7 am to 1 pm on the 11th with frequent wind gusts over 40 mph. The observer near Redridge reported a storm total snowfall of 14.5 inches ending on the morning of the 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm developed over the Plains and tracked northeast into the Upper Great Lakes. The storm dropped widespread heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the evening of the 10th into the afternoon of the 12th. Blizzard conditions also occurred over the Keweenaw Peninsula on the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Weather Service in Negaunee Township reported a storm total snowfall of 17.5 inches ending on the morning of the 12th. Water equivalent precipitation from the storm measured 2.90 inches including a daily record of 2.22 inches on the 11th. Northeast winds also gusted over 30 mph at times during the event.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Bergland reported eight inches of snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm developed over the Plains and tracked northeast into the Upper Great Lakes. The storm dropped widespread heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the evening of the 10th into the afternoon of the 12th. Blizzard conditions also occurred over the Keweenaw Peninsula on the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Marenisco reported a storm total snowfall of 12.5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system originating over the Plains deepened as it moved into the Western Great Lakes on March 31st. Snow mixed with rain and sleet over east and south central counties of Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 31st and then fell heavy at times through the evening of March 31st into April 1st. ||The combination of heavy snow and north winds gusting as high as 50 mph near the Lake Superior shore lead to blizzard conditions as well as numerous power outages over Marquette and Alger counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: From midnight to 11 am on the 1st frequent north wind gusts of 40 mph or greater were measured by the ASOS at K.I. Sawyer International Airport.  During the time of the strong winds, heavy snowfall occurred over the highlands of Marquette County, resulting in widespread blizzard conditions.  The heaviest total snowfall was measured over the highlands west of Marquette where 20 to 25 inches fell from Palmer to Ishpeming and Negaunee.||The combination of heavy wet snow and strong winds toppled several trees and caused power outages in the Marquette area that affected nearly |2,700 customers. The harsh winter weather also caused the Marquette County Courthouse and service centers to reduce operations.  Most schools were closed throughout the area due to the blizzard conditions.||The weather also forced the closure of Lakeshore Boulevard in Marquette from Hawley to Wright Street while the Michigan State Police reported numerous minor accidents throughout Marquette County due to the poor road conditions. One rollover accident reportedly caused minor injures to two Marquette women.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm developed over the Plains and tracked northeast into the Upper Great Lakes. The storm dropped widespread heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the evening of the 10th into the afternoon of the 12th. Blizzard conditions also occurred over the Keweenaw Peninsula on the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer 11 miles south of Kenton reported six to seven inches of snow along with wind gusts over 25 mph at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Spring snowmelt caused minor flooding over portions of the Michigamme River from the 23rd into the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along County Road LG during the spring snowmelt.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Spring snowmelt caused flooding of the Sturgeon River near Chassell from the 20th through the 26th. Flooding of the Sturgeon River also occurred near Alston from the 22nd through the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sturgeon River went above flood stage near Alston on the 22nd and remained above flood stage through April 25th.  Portions of Usitalo, Halonen, and Tahtinen Roads flooded while the Alston gauge was above flood stage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system originating over the Plains deepened as it moved into the Western Great Lakes on the 31st. Snow mixed with rain and sleet over east and south central counties of Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 31st and then fell heavy at times through the evening of the 31st and the morning of April 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wet snow mixed with rain and sleet at times on the evening of the 31st.  Snow accumulation by midnight was generally one to two inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of thunderstorms developed over Lake Michigan late in the evening on the 12th, as very moist air surged into the region.  These storms were severe as they moved onshore, producing damaging winds, large hail, and a brief tornado.  However, the biggest impact was from excessive rainfall, which produced unusually severe flooding in West Central Lower Michigan.  The Governor of Michigan declared a state of emergency for Manistee and Wexford Counties, along with other counties downstate.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread thunderstorm wind damage occurred across the south half of the city of Manistee, and especially between 2nd and 10th Streets.  Many trees were downed, and some structures were damaged, mainly by falling trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second day of cold temperatures aloft contributed to thunderstorm development in Northern Lower Michigan.  These storms were prolific hail producers.

A stationary boundary across the area combined with remnants of overnight convection. This interacted with moderate instability to allow for numerous thunderstorms, a few of which reached severe levels.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported tree limbs and a few trees down in and around Hillsdale.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An outflow boundary moving in from Wisconsin and Illinois, combined with moderate shear and instability to allow for the development of a line of strong to locally severe thunderstorms across far southern Lower Michigan. Some wind damage was reported in Berrien County, but the system weakened as it moved east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County officials reported a tree being blown down onto Snow Road near the intersection of Redbud and Gar in Berrien Springs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved from northeastern Indiana into portions of far southern Lower Michigan. Straight-line wind damage was reported across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement officials reported several trees down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved from northeastern Indiana into portions of far southern Lower Michigan. Straight-line wind damage was reported across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operators reported a tree down onto an occupied house. No injuries were reported. Damage is estimated at $10,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved from northeastern Indiana into portions of far southern Lower Michigan. Straight-line wind damage was reported across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported trees uprooted as well as power lines down in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Morning convection stabilized the area until early afternoon when strong heating and an approaching short wave and front set the stage for rapid thunderstorm development. While instability was considered moderate, steep mid-level lapse rates allowed for a favorable profile for large hail and damaging winds. The storms began as very proficient hail producers and evolved into causing wind damage as they evolved.

While instability was considered moderate, steep mid-level lapse rates allowed for a favorable profile for large hail and damaging winds. The storms began as very proficient hail producers and evolved into causing wind damage as they evolved.

NWS storm survey teams determined that one EF1 tornado struck Osceola county.  Another EF1 tornado struck Eaton county and continued into extreme western Ingham county before dissipating. Extensive damage was documented in association with both tornadoes.  Severe thunderstorms also produced numerous reports of wind damage and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A woman was killed when the wind flipped a large trailer on top of her.  This happened in Delta township on Mt. Hope highway between Nixon and Guinea roads.

A large area of thunderstorms developed over Lake Michigan late in the evening on the 12th, as very moist air surged into the region.  These storms were severe as they moved onshore, producing damaging winds, large hail, and a brief tornado.  However, the biggest impact was from excessive rainfall, which produced unusually severe flooding in West Central Lower Michigan.  The Governor of Michigan declared a state of emergency for Manistee and Wexford Counties, along with other counties downstate.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two spotters estimated winds at 60 mph.  Several trees were downed, and a pole barn was partially unroofed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first in a series of three thunderstorm complexes that affected the area during the 15th and 16th moved out of Illinois into far southern lower Michigan during the morning hours of the 15th. The storms varied in intensity occasionally becoming severe with a handful of wind damage reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County officials reported several trees and power lines down in and around the Buchanan area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first in a series of three thunderstorm complexes that affected the area during the 15th and 16th moved out of Illinois into far southern lower Michigan during the morning hours of the 15th. The storms varied in intensity occasionally becoming severe with a handful of wind damage reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County officials reported several trees were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Spring snowmelt caused flooding of the Sturgeon River near Chassell from the 20th through the 26th. Flooding of the Sturgeon River also occurred near Alston from the 22nd through the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sturgeon River went above flood stage near Chassell on the 20th, and remained above flood stage into the afternoon of the 26th. Flooding was observed on Sturgeon River, Aho, and Rajala Roads during this time although no property damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very unstable conditions, fast moving westerly flow, and an approaching short wave all contributed to a line of strong to severe thunderstorms. The southern part of this line extended into extreme southwestern Indiana where some wind damage was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines down were reported down in parts of the county, including the Coldwater area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A gravity wave was the probable cause of damaging wind in the Indian Lake area near Manistique on the evening of the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds flipped over a 60-foot boat dock, downed several trees and caused damage to a second dock, boat lift and canopy in the Indian Lake area near Manistique.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through southeast Michigan during the early evening hours of June 6th. With temperature climbing into the lower 90s during the afternoon, the airmass became quite unstable, leading to numerous severe thunderstorms which produced damaging winds. The strongest thunderstorm winds occurred at Howell and Saginaw, where winds reached at least 70 mph. As such, Saginaw saw the greatest amount of damage and power outages, with 12,000 residents losing electricity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous large tree limbs reported down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local Media reported hail large enough to break the windshield of an SUV.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong south winds developed on the afternoon of the 6th ahead of a deep low pressure system approaching from the northern Plains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fifteen-foot tall, five-inch diameter top section of poplar tree knocked downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong south winds developed on the afternoon of the 6th ahead of a deep low pressure system approaching from the northern Plains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds toppled a tree near the corner of Breitung Avenue and Roosevelt Street in Breitung Township east of Kingsford. The tree fell on nearby power lines and caught on fire.  Traffic was detoured for a short period of time as the Breitung Township Fire Department and Wisconsin Energies personnel responded to the incident and cut the tree down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong south winds developed on the afternoon of the 6th ahead of a deep low pressure system approaching from the northern Plains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement officials reported numerous reports of trees down across the Ironwood area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local media reported down trees and siding torn from homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two late evening thunderstorms produced wind gusts of 60 to 64 mph across Livingston and Genesee counties. No damage was reported however.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter estimated a 60 mph thunderstorm wind gust.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and wires reported down.

As such, Saginaw saw the greatest amount of damage and power outages, with 12,000 residents losing electricity.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A derecho swept through southeast Michigan on Sunday afternoon June 8th. This brought widespread wind damage and localized large hail to the region.  Enhanced wind damage, due to winds as high as 85 mph, affected Shiaweesee, Livingston, Genesee, Oakland, Lapeer, Macomb and St. Clair counties. Thousands of trees were lost, with significant property damage occurring as trees fell on houses and cars. This is the most widespread damage to occur over southeast Michigan in over a decade, as over 300,000 residents lost power. Over 10,000 residents were without power for a week or more, indicative of the extent of damage, which was estimated to be 100 million dollars.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Morning convection stabilized the area until early afternoon when strong heating and an approaching short wave and front set the stage for rapid thunderstorm development. While instability was considered moderate, steep mid-level lapse rates allowed for a favorable profile for large hail and damaging winds. The storms began as very proficient hail producers and evolved into causing wind damage as they evolved.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported trees and power lines down in and around the Waldron area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported numerous trees and power lines down across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first in a series of three thunderstorm complexes that affected the area during the 15th and 16th moved out of Illinois into far southern lower Michigan during the morning hours of the 15th. The storms varied in intensity occasionally becoming severe with a handful of wind damage reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported several trees being blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of thunderstorms developed over Lake Michigan late in the evening on the 12th, as very moist air surged into the region.  These storms were severe as they moved onshore, producing damaging winds, large hail, and a brief tornado.  However, the biggest impact was from excessive rainfall, which produced unusually severe flooding in West Central Lower Michigan.  The Governor of Michigan declared a state of emergency for Manistee and Wexford Counties, along with other counties downstate.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding lingered for several days after the heavy rain event ended, mainly on the Manistee River and its larger tributaries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large tree limbs reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter estimated a 60 mph thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon hours around the I-69 corridor.

A large area of thunderstorms developed over Lake Michigan late in the evening on the 12th, as very moist air surged into the region.  These storms were severe as they moved onshore, producing damaging winds, large hail, and a brief tornado.  However, the biggest impact was from excessive rainfall, which produced unusually severe flooding in West Central Lower Michigan.  The Governor of Michigan declared a state of emergency for Manistee and Wexford Counties, along with other counties downstate.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to six inches of rain fell in southwest and central Missaukee County, in the very early morning hours of the 13th.  This resulted in  flash flooding, with several roads washing out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of thunderstorms developed over Lake Michigan late in the evening on the 12th, as very moist air surged into the region.  These storms were severe as they moved onshore, producing damaging winds, large hail, and a brief tornado.  However, the biggest impact was from excessive rainfall, which produced unusually severe flooding in West Central Lower Michigan.  The Governor of Michigan declared a state of emergency for Manistee and Wexford Counties, along with other counties downstate.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding lingered for several days after the heavy rain event ended, mainly on the Manistee River and its larger tributaries.  The Manistee River at Sherman established a new flood of record on the 14th, reaching 16.4 feet.  Several homes just above Hodenpyl Dam Pond had to be evacuated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second day of cold temperatures aloft contributed to thunderstorm development in Northern Lower Michigan.  These storms were prolific hail producers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter estimated 60 mph wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Much like the day before, thunderstorms developed thanks to strong heating during the afternoon of the 22nd.  Several storms became severe, producing mainly large hail.  However, a few storms interacted with the Lake Huron lake breeze, resulting in a single tornado and locally excessive rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: EF1 tornado, with winds estimated up to 100 mph.  Tornado tracked through a heavily forested area, downing many trees west of Mount Maria Road, east of Consolidated Road, and north of the West Branch River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Much like the day before, thunderstorms developed thanks to strong heating during the afternoon of the 22nd.  Several storms became severe, producing mainly large hail.  However, a few storms interacted with the Lake Huron lake breeze, resulting in a single tornado and locally excessive rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of slow-moving thunderstorms dumped heavy rain across far southern Alcona County.  Radar estimated three to six inches of rainfall in Mikado and Greenbush Townships.  Flash flooding occurred on Grey and Roy Creeks, washing out several driveways and side roads, and closing parts of Alvin, Goddard, and London Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Much like the day before, thunderstorms developed thanks to strong heating during the afternoon of the 22nd.  Several storms became severe, producing mainly large hail.  However, a few storms interacted with the Lake Huron lake breeze, resulting in a single tornado and locally excessive rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water from earlier flash flooding lingered on a number of roads, especially along Roy and Grey Creeks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers and a few embedded thunderstorms moved across parts of Northern Lower Michigan during the evening of the 28th.  This line producing 50 to 60 mph winds at times.  In some cases, these winds downed small branches miles away from the parent storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two trees and several large limbs were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers and a few embedded thunderstorms moved across parts of Northern Lower Michigan during the evening of the 28th.  This line producing 50 to 60 mph winds at times.  In some cases, these winds downed small branches miles away from the parent storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and signs were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to severe thunderstorms produced pockets of wind damage, some of which was substantial, across East Central Lower Michigan.
A few severe thunderstorms developed during the early morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs, 12 inch in diameter, were reported down near East Hamburg Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm and humid air surged northward into Northern Michigan on the 6th.  A strong low pressure system moved into the region late in the day, helping to spawn numerous thunderstorms, several of which became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado touched down near intersection of M-33 and Sage Lake Road, and lifted about a mile to the northeast.  Several farms and residences suffered roof damage, some outbuildings were also damaged, and a number of trees and large limbs were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm and humid air surged northward into Northern Michigan on the 6th.  A strong low pressure system moved into the region late in the day, helping to spawn numerous thunderstorms, several of which became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two semi-trailers were overturned, the top of a barn silo was ripped off and blown half a mile away, a few roofs were damaged, and several trees and power lines were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to severe thunderstorms produced pockets of wind damage, some of which was substantial, across East Central Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread trees and power lines downed in the West Branch area.  Some damage to structures due to falling trees.  Considerable roof damage, including a few roofs completely blown off structures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second day of cold temperatures aloft contributed to thunderstorm development in Northern Lower Michigan.  These storms were prolific hail producers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines downed in and west of Tawas City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of thunderstorms developed over Lake Michigan late in the evening on the 12th, as very moist air surged into the region.  These storms were severe as they moved onshore, producing damaging winds, large hail, and a brief tornado.  However, the biggest impact was from excessive rainfall, which produced unusually severe flooding in West Central Lower Michigan.  The Governor of Michigan declared a state of emergency for Manistee and Wexford Counties, along with other counties downstate.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: EF0 tornado with estimated wind speeds 75 to 85 mph.  The tornado tracked through forested land near Skocelas Road, just south of M-55.  Numerous trees and large limbs were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of thunderstorms developed over Lake Michigan late in the evening on the 12th, as very moist air surged into the region.  These storms were severe as they moved onshore, producing damaging winds, large hail, and a brief tornado.  However, the biggest impact was from excessive rainfall, which produced unusually severe flooding in West Central Lower Michigan.  The Governor of Michigan declared a state of emergency for Manistee and Wexford Counties, along with other counties downstate.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters in Manistee and Wellston measured around six inches of rain in a few hours very late on the 12th into the pre-dawn hours of the 13th.  Radar estimated up to ten inches of rainfall along the southern border of Manistee County.  Substantial flash flooding resulted, with considerable soil erosion, thanks in part to the sandy soils of the area.  At one point the majority of roads in the south half of Manistee County were under water.  High water entered some homes.  In the city of Manistee, asphalt, stop signs, and light posts were flushed into Lake Michigan by the raging waters.  The county road commission estimated $500,000 in damages to the county road system.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of thunderstorms developed over Lake Michigan late in the evening on the 12th, as very moist air surged into the region.  These storms were severe as they moved onshore, producing damaging winds, large hail, and a brief tornado.  However, the biggest impact was from excessive rainfall, which produced unusually severe flooding in West Central Lower Michigan.  The Governor of Michigan declared a state of emergency for Manistee and Wexford Counties, along with other counties downstate.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding developed in southern Wexford County, with isolated flooding in the north, thanks to three to six inches of rainfall in a few hours either side of midnight.  Numerous roads were washed out, especially on the northwest side of Lake Cadillac, and near and north of Mesick.  One hundred and fifty homes were impacted by high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers and a few embedded thunderstorms moved across parts of Northern Lower Michigan during the evening of the 28th.  This line producing 50 to 60 mph winds at times.  In some cases, these winds downed small branches miles away from the parent storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers and a few embedded thunderstorms moved across parts of Northern Lower Michigan during the evening of the 28th.  This line producing 50 to 60 mph winds at times.  In some cases, these winds downed small branches miles away from the parent storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were downed in Grant Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers and a few embedded thunderstorms moved across parts of Northern Lower Michigan during the evening of the 28th.  This line producing 50 to 60 mph winds at times.  In some cases, these winds downed small branches miles away from the parent storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter estimated wind gusts to 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Much like the day before, thunderstorms developed thanks to strong heating during the afternoon of the 22nd.  Several storms became severe, producing mainly large hail.  However, a few storms interacted with the Lake Huron lake breeze, resulting in a single tornado and locally excessive rainfall.

A line of showers and a few embedded thunderstorms moved across parts of Northern Lower Michigan during the evening of the 28th.  This line producing 50 to 60 mph winds at times.  In some cases, these winds downed small branches miles away from the parent storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roofing was torn off of a self-storage building.  Three maple trees were downed near Prudenville.  A large oak tree was snapped off further east along M-55.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers and a few embedded thunderstorms moved across parts of Northern Lower Michigan during the evening of the 28th.  This line producing 50 to 60 mph winds at times.  In some cases, these winds downed small branches miles away from the parent storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large trees were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers and a few embedded thunderstorms moved across parts of Northern Lower Michigan during the evening of the 28th.  This line producing 50 to 60 mph winds at times.  In some cases, these winds downed small branches miles away from the parent storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Falling tree knocked down power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter measured a 60 mph thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A derecho swept through southeast Michigan on Sunday afternoon June 8th. This brought widespread wind damage and localized large hail to the region.  Enhanced wind damage, due to winds as high as 85 mph, affected Shiaweesee, Livingston, Genesee, Oakland, Lapeer, Macomb and St. Clair counties. Thousands of trees were lost, with significant property damage occurring as trees fell on houses and cars. This is the most widespread damage to occur over southeast Michigan in over a decade, as over 300,000 residents lost power. Over 10,000 residents were without power for a week or more, indicative of the extent of damage, which was estimated to be 100 million dollars.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A derecho swept through southeast Michigan on Sunday afternoon June 8th. This brought widespread wind damage and localized large hail to the region.  Enhanced wind damage, due to winds as high as 85 mph, affected Shiaweesee, Livingston, Genesee, Oakland, Lapeer, Macomb and St. Clair counties. Thousands of trees were lost, with significant property damage occurring as trees fell on houses and cars. This is the most widespread damage to occur over southeast Michigan in over a decade, as over 300,000 residents lost power. Over 10,000 residents were without power for a week or more, indicative of the extent of damage, which was estimated to be 100 million dollars.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary frontal boundary allowed for numerous severe thunderstorm development, with flash flooding occuring in Lapeer county.
A nearly stationary frontal boundary allowed for numerous severe thunderstorm development, with flash flooding occuring in Lapeer county.

Isolated thunderstorms developed in the afternoon in Northeast Lower Michigan, followed by a more widespread line of storms in the evening.  Isolated severe weather and flash flooding resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding lingered in the Hubbard Lake area through the night.  A few additional thunderstorms moved through the region, with radar estimates topping out at four to eight inches of rain during the afternoon and night of the 17th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed in the afternoon in Northeast Lower Michigan, followed by a more widespread line of storms in the evening.  Isolated severe weather and flash flooding resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Radar estimated three to five inches of rain fell during the late afternoon hours in the northern third of Alcona County.  Mount Maria Road was flooded near the south end of Hubbard Lake.  Hubbard Lake Road also went underwater, between Lake Street and Pine Grove Shores, as well as near Swede Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A single thunderstorm crossed Lake Michigan early in the afternoon, then blossomed into several small lines of storms in Northern Lower Michigan.  These storms produced damaging winds and large hail in spots.

A single thunderstorm crossed Lake Michigan early in the afternoon, then blossomed into several small lines of storms in Northern Lower Michigan.  These storms produced damaging winds and large hail in spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and many large limbs were downed, in a swath from near Garland to Comins.  Some power lines were also downed.  Pea sized hail also occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A single thunderstorm crossed Lake Michigan early in the afternoon, then blossomed into several small lines of storms in Northern Lower Michigan.  These storms produced damaging winds and large hail in spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees and several large limbs were downed.  One home was damaged by a falling tree.  The storm also produced half-inch diameter hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A single thunderstorm crossed Lake Michigan early in the afternoon, then blossomed into several small lines of storms in Northern Lower Michigan.  These storms produced damaging winds and large hail in spots.

A single thunderstorm crossed Lake Michigan early in the afternoon, then blossomed into several small lines of storms in Northern Lower Michigan.  These storms produced damaging winds and large hail in spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A swath of wind damage occurred from west of Gaylord, to central Otsego Lake.  Trees were downed along M-32, Hayes Tower Road, and West Otsego Lake Drive.  One very large limb was downed onto a cabin near the Beaver Creek Resort.  Some damage was done to boats and docks on Otsego Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A severe weather outbreak on July second resulted in numerous reports of wind damage and large hail.  The strong to severe thunderstorms also produced very heavy rain, flooding, and even flash flooding across portions of Kalamazoo county.||Strong winds with gusts over 60 mph, along with large areas of wind damage, occurred from Muskegon to Grand Rapids and Lansing, south to Kalamazoo. In parts of Allegan county, winds were estimated between 65 to 75 mph by the National Weather Service, which conducted a storm survey of the area. These winds brought down dozens of trees and snapped eight power poles southwest of Fennville. In northwest Kalamazoo county, the winds blew the roof off a home at 15th Street and 102nd Avenue.||Large hail of three quarters of an inch in diameter or greater was reported from Muskegon to Montcalm county, including southern Newaygo and northern Kent counties. Another area or large hail stretched from Allegan county east through Ingham county and south into Kalamazoo and Jackson counties. The hail was large enough to damage some crops. The largest hail was 1.75 inches near Morley and 1.5 inches near Lakewood Club in Muskegon county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported quarter sized hail near Olivet Station.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A severe weather outbreak on July second resulted in numerous reports of wind damage and large hail.  The strong to severe thunderstorms also produced very heavy rain, flooding, and even flash flooding across portions of Kalamazoo county.||Strong winds with gusts over 60 mph, along with large areas of wind damage, occurred from Muskegon to Grand Rapids and Lansing, south to Kalamazoo. In parts of Allegan county, winds were estimated between 65 to 75 mph by the National Weather Service, which conducted a storm survey of the area. These winds brought down dozens of trees and snapped eight power poles southwest of Fennville. In northwest Kalamazoo county, the winds blew the roof off a home at 15th Street and 102nd Avenue.||Large hail of three quarters of an inch in diameter or greater was reported from Muskegon to Montcalm county, including southern Newaygo and northern Kent counties. Another area or large hail stretched from Allegan county east through Ingham county and south into Kalamazoo and Jackson counties. The hail was large enough to damage some crops. The largest hail was 1.75 inches near Morley and 1.5 inches near Lakewood Club in Muskegon county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement near Olivet Station reported one and a quarter inch diameter hail that resulted in widespread damage to corn.  A five mile stretch of destroyed corn and wheat was reported along Martin Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance kicked off numerous showers and thunderstorm, resulting in locally heavy rain and isolated flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Radar estimated that two to four inches of rain fell in Butman Township between 1 and 3 PM EDT.  The resulting runoff caused localized flash flooding.  Water covered Sugar River Road, west of Leatonville Road.  Substantial roadbed erosion occurred along Hockaday Road, Ritchie Road just west of Hockaday, and at the intersection of Butman and Cemetary Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Much like the day before, thunderstorms developed thanks to strong heating during the afternoon of the 22nd.  Several storms became severe, producing mainly large hail.  However, a few storms interacted with the Lake Huron lake breeze, resulting in a single tornado and locally excessive rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny sized hail fell at Onaway State Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance trigged a few severe thunderstorms north of I-69.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain of 4 to 5 inches during the afternoon hours caused flash flooding across Bay City. The Bay-Arenac ISD Service Center and Career Center was closed due to flooding. At least a foot of standing water accumulated on Wilder Road. Several residents across Bay City also reported flooded basements.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced large hail and damaging wind over portions of central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail caused damage to cars.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced large hail and damaging wind over portions of central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail was estimated to be two inches in diameter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced large hail and damaging wind over portions of central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 1st.

Extensive flooding occurred across Kalamazoo county as a result of excessive rainfall which began on the twelfth and continued on the thirteenth and fourteenth. Many roads in the city of Kalamazoo were closed for several days and damage to public infrastructure (mostly roads and bridge washouts) was estimated at eleven million dollars.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure moving along a slow moving front and the remnants of Hurricane Ike brought heavy rain to Southwest Lower Michigan. The rain started on the twelfth and persisted through the thirteenth and fourteenth.  ||Rainfall totals were impressive and in excess of ten inches across portions of Kalamazoo county, including a report of 10.5 inches at Augusta.  The heaviest rain occurred along and just north of the Interstate 94 corridor across northern and central Kalamazoo county.||A local state of emergency was declared for Kalamazoo county and moderate river flooding occurred on the Kalamazoo river at Comstock.  Damage to public infrastructure (mostly road and bridge washouts) and to homes from flooding was estimated to exceed 11 million dollars.  ||The worst flooding occurred near Comstock, where the river rose to 10.43 feet, the third highest crest on record. Many homes and businesses downstream were flooded. Many roads in the city of Kalamazoo were closed for several days due to high water. ||In fact, in the city of Kalamazoo, ten businesses were flooded, 466 homes were flooded, and ten major street intersections in downtown Kalamazoo were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered two severe thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees down on power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two marginally severe thunderstorms developed along surface boundaries.
A weak upper level disturbance trigged two marginally severe thunderstorms.
A cold front triggered isolated severe thunderstorms over southeast Oakland and northwest Wayne Counties.
A cold front triggered isolated severe thunderstorms over southeast Oakland and northwest Wayne Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Media reported tree limbs and wires down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front combined with tropical moisture to spawn a tornado in Plymouth.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 918 PM Saturday September 13th a tornado occurred in parts of Plymouth and Livonia in Wayne County. The Tornado path length was 2.6 miles and began just west of Starkweather Street near the railroad tracks in Plymouth and tracked eastward across the intersection of Interstates 96 and 275 and ended in Livonia at the intersection of Newburgh and Richfield Roads near Ladywood High School. The maximum path width of the tornado was roughly 200 yards in Plymouth and was 100 yards or less in most other locations along its path. Most of the damage along the path was to trees and was rated mostly at the EF0 level (less than 86 MPH). However, a short stretch of significant roof damage occurred in Plymouth to two apartment buildings in Lake Pointe Village and Brougham Manor. This damage was rated at the EF2 level, or roughly winds to 120 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell over southeast Michigan from September 12th-14th, with widespread 3 to 6 inches reported. Isolated amounts around 8 inches were even reported across northwest Genesee County. A slow moving cold front interacting with the remnants of two tropical systems, one being Lowell from the Pacific and the other being Ike from the Atlantic, led to the extreme rainfall totals. This heavy rain did cause some widespread flooding across much of southeast Michigan, but mostly minor flooding was reported, such as large pools of water on roads, road closures, along with some basement flooding. One of the most significant reported flooding occurred in Farmington Hills, were residents of the Manor of Farmington Hills had to be evacuated as water flowed through the patients rooms. A Clinton Township woman also had to be rescued as her car became submerged at Millar and Utica Roads. In addition to the heavy rain, the remnants of Ike did cause some strong winds which caused small tree limbs to fall and power outages to around 15,000 customers spread across Macomb, St. Clair, and Oakland counties.

This heavy rain did cause some widespread flooding across much of southeast Michigan, but mostly minor flooding was reported, such as large pools of water on roads, road closures, along with some basement flooding. One of the most significant reported flooding occurred in Farmington Hills, were residents of the Manor of Farmington Hills had to be evacuated as water flowed through the patients rooms. A Clinton Township woman also had to be rescued as her car became submerged at Millar and Utica Roads. In addition to the heavy rain, the remnants of Ike did cause some strong winds which caused small tree limbs to fall and power outages to around 15,000 customers spread across Macomb, St. Clair, and Oakland counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained Spotters reported small tree limbs down, along with power outage of about 4000 customers.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell over southeast Michigan from September 12th-14th, with widespread 3 to 6 inches reported. Isolated amounts around 8 inches were even reported across northwest Genesee County. A slow moving cold front interacting with the remnants of two tropical systems, one being Lowell from the Pacific and the other being Ike from the Atlantic, led to the extreme rainfall totals. This heavy rain did cause some widespread flooding across much of southeast Michigan, but mostly minor flooding was reported, such as large pools of water on roads, road closures, along with some basement flooding. One of the most significant reported flooding occurred in Farmington Hills, were residents of the Manor of Farmington Hills had to be evacuated as water flowed through the patients rooms. A Clinton Township woman also had to be rescued as her car became submerged at Millar and Utica Roads. In addition to the heavy rain, the remnants of Ike did cause some strong winds which caused small tree limbs to fall and power outages to around 15,000 customers spread across Macomb, St. Clair, and Oakland counties.

The Huron River at Hamburg reached its 4th highest stage on record due to heavy rain of close to 6 inches which fell during the weekend of September 13th to 14th. This major flood caused many roads, yards, and some roads to flood around Ore Lake and along the reach of the Huron River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Huron River at Hamburg crested at 7.6 feet during the morning of September 18th.

Moderate Flooding occured along the middle and north branch of the Clinton River due to heavy rain of close to 6 inches which fell during the weekend of September 13th to 14th. Several roads were closed due to flooding, as well as parks, golf courses, and yards flooded.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Clinton River in Clinton Township crested at 18.32 feet during the evening of September 14th, while the Clinton River near Mount Clemens crested at 16.16 feet during the morning hours of September 16th.

Moisture from the remnants of Tropical Storm Lowell and Hurricane Ike moved into the region and interacted with a stationary boundary to bring heavy rainfall to portions of far southern lower Michigan starting on the 11th, extending into the early morning hours of the 15th. Widespread reports of 8 to as much as 12 inches of rain were received across Berrien and Cass counties. A portion of the Niles Dam suffered a breach in the earthen part. Downstream residents were evacuated as a precaution.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The rainfall from the remnants of Lowell and Ike continued to drop heavy rainfall into the early morning hours of the 15th. When the rain finally stopped, total rainfall amounts of over 12 inches was reported in the Buchanan and Niles area. Numerous roads remained closed with some culverts and bridges suffering damage. The Pucker Street Dam in Niles suffered a partial breech on an earthen part of the dam. Roughly a eight foot section was washed away, forcing the evacuation of residents downstream of the dam. No injuries were reported. No exact figures are available for the damage to the area from the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from the remnants of Tropical Storm Lowell and Hurricane Ike moved into the region and interacted with a stationary boundary to bring heavy rainfall to portions of far southern lower Michigan starting on the 11th, extending into the early morning hours of the 15th. Widespread reports of 8 to as much as 12 inches of rain were received across Berrien and Cass counties. A portion of the Niles Dam suffered a breach in the earthen part. Downstream residents were evacuated as a precaution.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The rainfall from the remnants of Lowell and Ike continued to drop heavy rainfall into the early morning hours of the 15th. When the rain finally stopped, total rainfall amounts of eight to ten inches was reported across the southern part of the county, including the Three Rivers area. Numerous roads remained closed with some culverts and bridges suffering damage.  No injuries were reported. No exact figures are available for the damage to the area from the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from the remnants of Tropical Storm Lowell and Hurricane Ike moved into the region and interacted with a stationary boundary to bring heavy rainfall to portions of far southern lower Michigan starting on the 11th, extending into the early morning hours of the 15th. Widespread reports of 8 to as much as 12 inches of rain were received across Berrien and Cass counties. A portion of the Niles Dam suffered a breach in the earthen part. Downstream residents were evacuated as a precaution.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The rainfall from the remnants of Lowell and Ike continued to drop heavy rainfall into the early morning hours of the 15th. When the rain finally stopped, total rainfall amounts of 10 to 12 inches was reported from the extreme eastern parts of Niles into Edwardsburg. Numerous roads remained closed with some culverts and bridges suffering damage.  No injuries were reported. No exact figures are available for the damage to the area from the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from the remnants of Tropical Storm Lowell and Hurricane Ike moved into the region and interacted with a stationary boundary to bring heavy rainfall to portions of far southern lower Michigan starting on the 11th, extending into the early morning hours of the 15th. Widespread reports of 8 to as much as 12 inches of rain were received across Berrien and Cass counties. A portion of the Niles Dam suffered a breach in the earthen part. Downstream residents were evacuated as a precaution.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported numerous roads in the southern part of the county being flooded, some with water as deep as one foot flowing over the road. This resulted in the closure of some roads, especially in the Niles area. Rainfall reports of up to 5 inches were noted across the area. Areal flooding continued into the 15th as additional rainfall occurred. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front dropping south through the Great Lakes. 30 to 40 knots of shear as well as a moist unstable atmosphere allowed for several small bowing segments to develop with areas of wind damage reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement officials reported several trees down in Burr Oak.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold west-northwest winds brought the first substantial lake effect snow event of the season to parts of Northern Lower Michigan.  Six to ten inches of snow fell in an area roughly bounded by Gaylord, Frederic, Mancelona, and Alba.

Cold west-northwest winds brought the first substantial lake effect snow event of the season to parts of Northern Lower Michigan.  Six to ten inches of snow fell in an area roughly bounded by Gaylord, Frederic, Mancelona, and Alba.

Cold west-northwest winds brought the first substantial lake effect snow event of the season to parts of Northern Lower Michigan.  Six to ten inches of snow fell in an area roughly bounded by Gaylord, Frederic, Mancelona, and Alba.

An Alberta Clipper moved through the Northern Great Lakes on the 19th, producing mostly light snow.  However, southwest winds ahead of the clipper scooped up extra moisture from Lake Michigan, and then dumped locally heavy snow on parts of Eastern Upper Michigan.  Raber picked up 10 inches of snow, Tahquamenon Falls had just over 9 inches, while Engadine had 8 and Sault Ste Marie, 7 inches.

A warm front lifted north across southwest Michigan during the afternoon hours. An abundant amount of moisture and strong southwest flow combined to produce thunderstorms across the region. As a result, four tornadoes were spawned from a single thunderstorm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down just west of Paw Paw. Uprooted trees and broken limbs were found along with a twisted metal fence near a school. The tornado then moved into the southern section of the town of Paw Paw. Damage to a car dealership occurred when a section of metal roof was ripped off.  A restaurant also sustained damage when trees were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted north across southwest Michigan during the afternoon hours. An abundant amount of moisture and strong southwest flow combined to produce thunderstorms across the region. As a result, four tornadoes were spawned from a single thunderstorm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were snapped or uprooted from the tornado. A home sustained damage when a tree fell on it. Debris, including outdoor furniture, was tossed into a nearby cornfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clusters of strong thunderstorms moved across Northeast Lower Michigan in the late afternoon and evening hours. One storm produced penny sized hail.

A warm front lifted north across southwest Michigan during the afternoon hours. An abundant amount of moisture and strong southwest flow combined to produce thunderstorms across the region. As a result, four tornadoes were spawned from a single thunderstorm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree branches were snapped off when a brief tornado occurred. This tornado was on the ground for less than one minute before lifting.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous large tree limbs reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface trough moving through southeast Michigan during the afternoon hours triggered scattered severe thunderstorms along and near an Adrian to Port Huron line.

Deepening low pressure moved into northwestern Wisconsin with a strong cold front extending from it into the southern Great Lakes. Abundant moisture and a strong wind field set the state for a line of strong to severe storms to move into extreme southern Lower Michigan during the late evening hours of April 25th into the early morning hours of the 26th. While most activity remained below severe limits, a small cluster of storms was able to tap the strong wind fields and cause damaging winds in some areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local law enforcement reported a tree down across the a road in Sturgis.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorm wind gusts resulted in several reports of significant wind damage.  Several reports of large hail were also received.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement estimated wind gusts in excess of 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms resulted in numerous reports of large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter in Mears reported pea to quarter sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms resulted in numerous reports of large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One inch diameter hail was measured near the twin bridges at Hamlin Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to severe thunderstorms produced pockets of wind damage, some of which was substantial, across East Central Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many trees and power lines were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to severe thunderstorms produced pockets of wind damage, some of which was substantial, across East Central Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sporadic trees and power lines downed a mile south of Albright Shores.  Some damage to a barn and to the roof of a home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved from northeastern Indiana into portions of far southern Lower Michigan. Straight-line wind damage was reported across the area.
Severe thunderstorm wind gusts resulted in several reports of significant wind damage.  Several reports of large hail were also received.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two healthy eight inch diameter trees were blown down at Ridley road north of Kinneyville road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rare mid winter severe weather event occurred and resulted in several reports of high winds and large hail.  There were few reports of damage associated with the severe weather.  However hail did briefly cover the ground near Mt. Pleasant, and one tree was blown down just southeast of Spring Arbor.  Two funnel clouds were also reported near Mt. Pleasant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported street flooding at the intersection of Getty and Sherman with water estimated at eight inches deep.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second day of cold temperatures aloft contributed to thunderstorm development in Northern Lower Michigan.  These storms were prolific hail producers.
Severe thunderstorms resulted in numerous reports of large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported one inch diameter hail in Custer.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorm wind gusts resulted in several reports of significant wind damage.  Several reports of large hail were also received.
