EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A round of severe thunderstorms resulted in numerous reports of large hail during the afternoon hours of April the eleventh.  Hail briefly covered the ground at several locations and there were several reports of broken windshields from hail in Parma in Jackson county.
Cold air aloft contributed to numerous thunderstorms during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 14th.  Several storms became severe, producing mainly large hail.
Severe thunderstorms resulted in numerous reports of large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported one inch diameter hail in Custer.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms resulted in numerous reports of large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One inch diameter hail was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through southeast Michigan during the early evening hours of June 6th. With temperature climbing into the lower 90s during the afternoon, the airmass became quite unstable, leading to numerous severe thunderstorms which produced damaging winds. The strongest thunderstorm winds occurred at Howell and Saginaw, where winds reached at least 70 mph. As such, Saginaw saw the greatest amount of damage and power outages, with 12,000 residents losing electricity.
Two rounds of thunderstorms affected southeast Michigan, one during the early afternoon hours, with the second round occuring during the evening hours associated with a cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down on a powerline at Quanicassee and Akron Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced large hail and damaging wind over portions of central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Funnel cloud was spotted in the Lake Bluff area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms resulted in numerous reports of large hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service storm survey determined that an EF1 tornado struck the Nordhouse Dunes region of the Manistee National Forest north of Ludington.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: It was determined that an EF1 tornado struck the Nordhouse Dunes region of the Manistee National Forest north of Ludington.  The track was about 1.3 miles long with a maximum path width of about 300 yards.  It touched down on the beach at 8:26 PM EST on June 12th and was on the ground for about two minutes before lifting.||Initial aerial photography of the forest blowdown received by the NWS was interpreted as straightline wind damage, but recent ground surveys have confirmed a pattern of damage consistent with a broadly rotating wind.  The tornado formed at the head of a bowing thunderstorm segment.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service storm survey determined that an EF1 tornado struck the Nordhouse Dunes region of the Manistee National Forest north of Ludington.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported several trees and power lines were blown down in the Ludington and Hamlin Lake areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorm wind gusts resulted in several reports of significant wind damage.  Several reports of large hail were also received.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm resulted in a report of one inch diameter hail.  A lightning strike resulted in a gas well fire in Ensley Center in Newaygo county, resulting in significant damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One inch diameter hail was reported at I-96 and 68th street near Coopersville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: NWS storm survey teams determined that one EF1 tornado struck Osceola county.  Another EF1 tornado struck Eaton county and continued into extreme western Ingham county before dissipating. Extensive damage was documented in association with both tornadoes.  Severe thunderstorms also produced numerous reports of wind damage and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm survey team determined that an EF1 tornado developed over Cochran road about four miles southwest of Grand Ledge.  Though briefly weakening to EF0 status shortly after descent... the tornado regained it's EF1 status before finally lifting immediately east of the Eckert Plant in Lansing.||Some large tree limbs were blown down and a few spruce trees were uprooted by winds estimated to be up to 63 mph along Mulliken road and Needmore highway. More significant damage was noted on Cochran road north of Needmore highway.  Numerous trees and limbs were blown down... a porch awning was blown off and a garage was completely destroyed.   An EF1 tornado rating was assigned for the damage on Cochran road. ||The tornado continued on Strange highway briefly weakening to EF0.   Multiple large trees were uprooted along Strange highway approaching M-100 (Hartel road).  Moderate to significant roof damage was observed on four different homes heading north on M-100 where the tornado regained it's EF1 status.  ||Dozens of large spruces and maples were uprooted on Mt. Hope highway |and four barns were destroyed.  Significant roof damage to homes reappeared as well.  A woman was killed when a large trailer was flipped on top of her in Delta township on Mt. Hope highway between Nixon and Guinea roads.  ||The tornado continued toward a subdivision on the west side of Lansing. |Numerous large trees were uprooted on North Cambridge road and a few landed on homes.  The country club of Lansing was also affected by downed trees and limbs as the tornado moved into far western Ingham county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced several reports of damaging wind gusts and also caused significant flooding.  In fact a presidential disaster declaration was issued for Allegan, Barry, Eaton and Ottawa counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads across portions of Barry county were washed out by very heavy rain.  In fact a half a million dollars worth of damage resulted primarily from washed out roads.  Due to the extensive flooding a presidential disaster declaration was issued.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A round of strong to severe thunderstorms accompanied by very heavy rainfall resulted in significant flash flooding across Mason and Lake counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Damage resulting from flash flooding included a 30 foot wide by 10 foot deep sinkhole which developed near the 18 Mile bridge five miles west of Irons.  Numerous roads were washed out and several mudslides were also reported. ||Rainfall totals across the areas hardest hit ranged from five to eleven inches, all of which fell in only a six to eight hour time period. Damage to public infrastructure was estimated at about two million dollars, mainly due to all of the road and bridge washouts. A presidential disaster declaration for flooding was also issued for Lake county.

Severe thunderstorms also produced numerous reports of wind damage and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported that an estimated wind gust to 70 mph took down some large trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A round of strong to severe thunderstorms accompanied by very heavy rainfall resulted in significant flash flooding across Mason and Lake counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Michigan Department of Transportation shut down U.S. 31 from Manistee to Scottville when the road washed out.  There were four washouts on M-116 on the drive to Ludington State Park.  One of those washouts was eight feet deep.  The Department of Natural Resources evacuated and then closed Ludington State Park due to flooding and concerns about the Hamlin Lake Dam. Mason county officials shut down 47 roads due to flooding and washouts.  ||Damage to public infrastructure (mostly road and bridge washouts) was estimated to have reached close to three million dollars for this event.  A presidential disaster declaration for flooding was issued for Mason county.  The hardest hit areas received up to eleven inches of rain in only six to eight hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: NWS storm survey teams determined that one EF1 tornado struck Osceola county.  Another EF1 tornado struck Eaton county and continued into extreme western Ingham county before dissipating. Extensive damage was documented in association with both tornadoes.  Severe thunderstorms also produced numerous reports of wind damage and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported that trees were blown down and that a tree and some debris were lifted up into the air.

Severe thunderstorms also produced numerous reports of wind damage and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees were blown down.  A large and healthy 60 foot tall maple tree was uprooted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A round of strong to severe thunderstorms accompanied by very heavy rainfall resulted in significant flash flooding across Mason and Lake counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An emergency manager reported that the Mackinaw trail just south of the Osceola and Wexford county line was washed out.  Other small roadways and bridges were also closed due to washouts.  A presidential disaster declaration was issued for Osceola county for the flooding.  Damage to public infrastructure (mostly road and bridge washouts) was estimated at up to around one million dollars for this event.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A building under construction located near the entrance to the Watermark Country Club collapsed due to high winds.  About two dozen trees were blown down from Cascade Road extending north and ending in the graveyard just north of Fulton St and just west of the Amway Headquarters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: NWS storm survey teams determined that one EF1 tornado struck Osceola county.  Another EF1 tornado struck Eaton county and continued into extreme western Ingham county before dissipating. Extensive damage was documented in association with both tornadoes.  Severe thunderstorms also produced numerous reports of wind damage and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm survey team in Osceola county determined that a tornado with peak winds approaching 110 mph struck an area from just northeast of Hersey to the Pere Marquette Forest.  This corresponds to EF-1 damage on the Enhanced Fujita Scale.  ||Damage occurred along an intermittent path about five miles long and up to a half a mile wide.  The most intense damage occurred along Cedar road in the Pere Marquette Forest... where a half mile wide section of forest was flattened.  Other significant damage occurred about four miles east of Reed City... where winds estimated at around 90 mph damaged a barn and trapped the occupants of a house until the day after the storm. ||The tornado occurred within a larger area of downburst wind damage that extended east northeast about 20 miles... beginning one mile northwest of Hersey to the Clare county line west of Lake George.  Thousands of trees were snapped or uprooted and several barns and outbuildings were damaged by the winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The EF1 tornado continued into northwestern Ingham county where it created it's final burst of damage at the Lansing Board of Water and Light Eckert Plant on Grand River avenue just south of Logan street.  One cooling tower was completely destroyed and another was severely damaged. The tornado rapidly weakened and lifted immediately to the east of the plant.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 3 a.m. EST June 8th, two people drowned when they were delivering newspapers and their car plunged into a fifty foot ravine created by a washed out road. A presidential disaster declaration was issued for Allegan county due to extensive flash flooding.
